revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:15,16-Dihydroxy-''alpha''-eleostearic acid}} {{Chembox | verifiedrevid = 406641642 | Name = 15,16-Dihydroxy-α-eleostearic acid | ImageFile = 15,16-Dihydroxy-alpha-eleostearic acid.svg | ImageSize = 200px | ImageAlt = | IUPACName = (9''Z'',11''E'',13''E'')-15,16-Dihydroxyoctadeca-9,11,13-trienoic acid | OtherNames = |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | CASNo = 1083078-83-4 | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | PubChem = 25156647 | ChemSpiderID = 57558074 | StdInChI=1S/C18H30O4/c1-2-16(19)17(20)14-12-10-8-6-4-3-5-7-9-11-13-15-18(21)22/h4,6,8,10,12,14,16-17,19-20H,2-3,5,7,9,11,13,15H2,1H3,(H,21,22)/b6-4-,10-8+,14-12+ | StdInChIKey = OBMDTPZEEDLBKM-ZMLXCLEUSA-N | SMILES = OC(CCCCCCC/C=C\C=C\C=C\C(O)C(O)CC)=O}} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | C=18 | H=30 | O=4 | Appearance = | Density = | MeltingPt = | BoilingPt = | Solubility = }} |Section3={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards = | FlashPt = | AutoignitionPt = }} }}
'''15,16-Dihydroxy-α-eleostearic acid''', or '''15,16-Dihydroxy-(9Z,11E,13E)-9,11,13-octadecatrienoic acid''', is an [[organic compound]] with formula {{chem|C|18|H|30|O|4}}, or H<sub>3</sub>C-CH<sub>2</sub>-(-CH(OH)-)<sub>2</sub>(-CH=CH-)<sub>3</sub>-(-CH<sub>2</sub>-)<sub>7</sub>-(C=O)OH. It can be seen as derived from [[alpha-eleostearic acid|α-eleostearic acid]] by the replacement of two [[hydrogen]] atoms by two [[hydroxyl]] (OH) groups.
The compound is found in the pulp and seeds of [[bitter melon]]s (the fruits of ''Momordica charantia''). It has been found to induce [[apoptosis]] in [[HL60]] [[leukemia]] cells [[in vitro]] at a concentration of 160 [[micromolar|μM]], although it is less potent in this regard than the unsubstituted α-eleostearic acid (also found in the seed oil). While α-eleostearic acid has been found to prevent [[carcinogenesis]] in [[rat]]s, this derivative does not seem to have that effect.<ref name="kob2008">Masuko Kobori, Mayumi Ohnishi-Kameyama, Yukari Akimoto, Chizuko Yukizaki and Mitsuru Yoshida (2008) ''α-Eleostearic Acid and Its Dihydroxy Derivative Are MajorApoptosis-Inducing Components of Bitter Gourd''. Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, volume 56, issue 22, pages 10515–10520. {{doi|10.1021/jf8020877}} </ref>
The compound can be extracted from the fruit with [[ethanol]], and is soluble in [[ethyl acetate]] but not in water or [[acetone]].
==See also== * [[alpha-eleostearic acid|α-Eleostearic acid]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dihydroxy-alpha-eleostearic acid, 15,16-}} [[Category:Fatty acids]]

page.title: Air travel disruption after the 2010 Eyjafjallajökull eruption

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/2.30.9.222|2.30.9.222]] to version by InternetArchiveBot. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3550682) (Bot)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[File:Eyjafjallajökull volcanic ash composite.png|thumb|Composite map of the volcanic [[ash cloud]] (with [[Eyjafjallajökull]] volcano in red) spanning 14–25 April 2010, based on data by the London Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre's website<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/aviation/vaac/vaacuk_vag.html|title=Met Office: Volcanic Ash Advisory from London - Issued graphics|first=Met|last=Office|date=|website=www.metoffice.gov.uk|accessdate=6 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180408200521/https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/aviation/vaac/vaacuk_vag.html|archivedate=8 April 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ([[Met Office]], UK).]] In response to concerns that [[volcanic ash]] ejected during the [[2010 eruptions of Eyjafjallajökull]] in Iceland would damage [[aircraft engine]]s,<ref>{{Cite news | title= Iceland volcano: Why a cloud of ash has grounded flights |work=BBC News| date= 15 April 2010 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8621992.stm | accessdate=19 April 2010 | first=Victoria | last=Gill| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130601161610/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8621992.stm| archivedate=1 June 2013<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> the [[controlled airspace]] of many European countries was closed to [[instrument flight rules]] traffic, resulting in the largest air-traffic shut-down since World War II.<ref name=SMH2>{{Cite news | title= Qantas cancels flights for a third day | work= The Sydney Morning Herald | date= 18 April 2010 | url= http://www.smh.com.au/travel/travel-news/qantas-cancels-flights-for-a-third-day-20100418-slv5.html | accessdate= 18 April 2010 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110605142411/http://www.smh.com.au/travel/travel-news/qantas-cancels-flights-for-a-third-day-20100418-slv5.html | archivedate= 5 June 2011 | df= dmy-all }}</ref> The closures caused millions of passengers to be [[wikt:strand#Verb|stranded]] not only in Europe, but across the world. With large parts of European airspace closed to air traffic,<ref name="NASInfo">{{cite web|url=http://www.norwegian.com/en/landingssider/cancellations-due-to-volcanic-ash-in-the-air/ |title=Cancellations due to volcanic ash in the air |date=15 April 2010 |publisher=[[Norwegian Air Shuttle]] |accessdate=15 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20100418203624/http://www.norwegian.com/en/landingssider/cancellations-due-to-volcanic-ash-in-the-air/ |archivedate=18 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=SFC15042010>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2010/04/15/bloomberg1376-L0WS531A74E9-1.DTL |title=Iceland Volcano Spewing Ash Chokes Europe Air Travel |date=15 April 2010 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=15 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821063035/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fg%2Fa%2F2010%2F04%2F15%2Fbloomberg1376-L0WS531A74E9-1.DTL |archivedate=21 August 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name=BBCNews8622438>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8622438.stm |title=Live: Volcanic cloud over Europe |publisher=BBC News |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100507122114/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8622438.stm| archivedate=7 May 2010<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> many more countries were affected as flights to, from, and over Europe were cancelled.
After an initial uninterrupted shutdown over much of northern Europe from 15 to 23 April, airspace was closed intermittently in different parts of Europe in the following weeks, as the path of the ash cloud was tracked. The [[ash cloud]] caused further disruptions to air travel operations in Ireland, Northern Ireland, and [[Scotland]] on 4 and 5 May<ref>{{citation|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8661096.stm |title= Scottish, Irish and Northern Irish airports shut by ash|publisher=BBC News |date=5 May 2010|accessdate=5 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100506032139/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8661096.stm| archivedate= 6 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and in Spain, Portugal, northern Italy, Austria, and southern Germany on 9 May.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news/international/europe/view.bg?articleid=1253427 |title=Ash closes airports in Spain, Portugal, Italy |publisher=Boston Herald |date=9 May 2010|accessdate=9 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100510171048/http://www.bostonherald.com/news/international/europe/view.bg?articleid=1253427| archivedate= 10 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Irish and UK airspace closed again on 16 May and reopened on 17 May.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0517/breaking1.html |title=Flights resuming normal service as airports reopen |work=The Irish Times |date=17 May 2010 |accessdate=17 May 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101118145048/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0517/breaking1.html |archivedate=18 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The eruption occurred beneath [[glacier|glacial ice]]. The cold water from the melting ice chilled the [[lava]] quickly, causing it to fragment into very small particles of glass ([[silica]]) and ash, which were carried into the [[Eruption column|eruption plume]]. The extremely fine ash particles and the large volume of steam from the glacial [[wikt:meltwater|meltwater]] sent an ash plume [[Volcanic ash#Aircraft|hazardous to aircraft]] rapidly high into the [[upper atmosphere]].<ref name=Guardian9032564>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/9032564 |title=Iceland's volcanic ash halts flights across Europe |work=The Guardian |date=15 April 2010|accessdate=17 April 2010 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100423175956/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/feedarticle/9032564| archivedate= 23 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The presence and location of the plume depended upon the state of the eruption and the winds. The large amount of glacial meltwater flowing into the eruption vent made this eruption so explosive that it injected its ash plume directly into the [[jet stream]], which was unusually stable and south-easterly.<ref name=Newsweek16042010>{{Cite news| author= Schechter, Olya| title= Smoked Out: Why Volcanic Ash and Planes Fight for the Same Small Airspace| work= Newsweek| date= 16 April 2010| url= http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/thehumancondition/archive/2010/04/16/smoked-out-why-volcanic-ash-and-planes-fight-for-the-same-small-air-space.aspx| accessdate= 17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100419004949/http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/thehumancondition/archive/2010/04/16/smoked-out-why-volcanic-ash-and-planes-fight-for-the-same-small-air-space.aspx| archivedate= 19 April 2010| deadurl= yes| df= dmy-all}}</ref> The ash was then carried over Europe into some of the busiest airspace in the world.
The [[International Air Transport Association]] (IATA) estimated that the airline industry worldwide would lose {{€|148 million}} ({{US$|200 million}}, {{GBP|130 million}}) a day during the disruption.<ref>{{Cite news |author= Wearden, Graeme |title= Ash cloud costing airlines £130m a day |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/apr/16/iceland-volcano-airline-industry-iata |work=The Guardian |date= 16 April 2010 |accessdate=17 April 2010 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418055656/http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2010/apr/16/iceland-volcano-airline-industry-iata| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> IATA stated that the total loss for the airline industry was around US$1.7 billion (£1.1 billion, €1.3 billion).<ref>{{cite news|title=Flight disruptions cost airlines $1.7bn, says IATA|date=21 April 2010|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8634147.stm|accessdate=24 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110512035008/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8634147.stm| archivedate= 12 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Airport Operators Association]] (AOA) estimated that airports lost £80 million over the six-and-a-half days.<ref>{{cite news|title=Volcano ash cloud: winners and losers|date=25 April 2010|first=Alastair|last=Jamieson|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/7631576/Volcano-ash-cloud-winners-and-losers.html|accessdate=24 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131064718/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/7631576/Volcano-ash-cloud-winners-and-losers.html|archivedate=31 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Over 95,000 flights had been cancelled all across Europe during the six-day travel ban,<ref>{{cite news|title=Ash cloud chaos: Airlines face huge task as ban ends|date=21 April 2010|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8633892.stm|accessdate=24 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812065242/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8633892.stm|archivedate=12 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> with later figures suggesting 107,000 flights cancelled during an 8-day period, accounting for 48% of total air traffic and roughly 10 million passengers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Volcanic eruptions: Science and Risk Management|date=27 May 2011|first=Bente Lilja|last=Bye|work=Science 2.0|url=http://www.science20.com/planetbye/volcanic_eruptions_science_and_risk_management-79456|accessdate=28 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529002746/http://www.science20.com/planetbye/volcanic_eruptions_science_and_risk_management-79456|archivedate=29 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Background ==
[[File:Volcanic Lavender.jpg|thumb| Dust particles suspended in the atmosphere scatter light from the setting sun, generating 'volcanic lavenders' like this one over the flight path of [[Leeds-Bradford Airport]] in England during the aviation shutdown]] The London [[Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre]] (VAAC) was responsible for providing information about the [[volcanic ash|ash plume]] to the relevant [[civil aviation authority|civil aviation authorities]] in the form of Volcanic Ash Advisories (VAA). On the basis of this, the authorities made decisions about when and where airspace should be closed due to the safety issues. Their decisions resulted in the cancellations of flights at airports across the world, not only in those countries where airspace was restricted. On 16 April 2010, 16,000 of Europe's usual 28,000 daily scheduled passenger flights were cancelled and on the following day 16,000 of the usual 22,000 flights were cancelled.<ref name="VoA17April">{{cite web|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/europe/Disrupted-Air-Travel-in-Northern-Europe-for-Third-Full-Day-91209609.html|title=Disrupted Air Travel in Northern Europe for Third Full Day|last=Hennessy|first=Selah|date=17 April 2010|publisher=Voice of America|accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420052257/http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/europe/Disrupted-Air-Travel-in-Northern-Europe-for-Third-Full-Day-91209609.html| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> By 21 April 95,000 flights had been cancelled.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8633892.stm "Ash cloud chaos: Airlines face huge task as ban ends"] BBC News, 21 April 2010</ref>
Before this, the severest restrictions to air travel in recent times were following the [[September 11 attacks|attacks of 11 September 2001 in the United States]] when all civil air traffic (not just scheduled) in US airspace, and to and from the United States, was grounded for three days.
[[Bill McGuire (volcanologist)|Professor Bill McGuire]] of the Aon Benfield UCL Hazard Research Centre said on 15 April that the most notable eruption of the [[Volcanism of Iceland|Icelandic volcano]] [[Laki]] which occurred in 1783,<ref>"[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2006/11/061121232204.htm Icelandic Volcano Caused Historic Famine In Egypt, Study Shows] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117013900/http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2006/11/061121232204.htm |date=17 January 2013 }}" ''ScienceDaily'' 22 November 2006</ref> would, if it occurred today "have the potential to severely affect air travel at high northern latitudes for six months or more". The last time the [[Eyjafjallajökull]] [[volcano]] erupted, in 1821, it spewed ash for over a year.<ref>"[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/36556083/ns/us_news-environment/ Volcano could mean cooling, acid rain] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418200951/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/36556083/ns/us_news-environment |date=18 April 2010 }}" MSNBC, 15 April 2010</ref> [[Geophysicist]]s in Iceland said that the production of ash from Eyjafjallajökull was likely to continue at a comparable level for some days or even weeks; a geophysicist at the Icelandic Meteorological Office said, "Where it disrupts travel depends on the weather. It depends how the wind carries the [[volcanic ash|ash]]".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/apr/15/iceland-volcano-ash-flights-grounded "Volcano chaos as Iceland eruption empties skies in Britain"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160721051829/https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/apr/15/iceland-volcano-ash-flights-grounded |date=21 July 2016 }} ''The Guardian'' newspaper, 16 April 2010</ref>
==Jet engine tolerance to airborne particles==
In 1982, [[British Airways Flight 9]] flew through volcanic ash of [[Mount Galunggung]], [[Java]], Indonesia, causing all 4 engines to shut down. However, the crew restarted all but one of the engines and [[emergency landing|landed safely]]. Subsequently, there was an addition to the operations manuals, describing how to deal with volcanic ash.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/content/2010/s2909102.htm |title=ABC News – Foreign Correspondent – May – transcript |publisher=ABC |location=Australia |accessdate=21 June 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100622032848/http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/content/2010/s2909102.htm| archivedate= 22 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Iceland's authorities had been warning the airlines for several years, asking them to determine the density of ash that is safe for their jet engines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/content/2010/s2909102.htm |title=Iceland – World, Interrupted – Foreign Correspondent |publisher=ABC |accessdate=21 June 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100622032848/http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/content/2010/s2909102.htm| archivedate= 22 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
But before the volcanic events of April 2010, aircraft engine manufacturers still had not defined specific particle levels above which engines were considered to be at risk.{{ref}} The general approach taken by airspace regulators was that if the ash concentration rose above zero, then the airspace was considered unsafe and was consequently closed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn18797-can-we-fly-safely-through-volcanic-ash.html |title=Can we fly safely through volcanic ash? – tech – 20 April 2010 |publisher=New Scientist |accessdate=21 June 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100423054540/http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn18797-can-we-fly-safely-through-volcanic-ash.html |archivedate=23 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The April eruption of Eyjafjallajökull caused enough economic difficulties that aircraft manufacturers were forced to define specific limits on how much ash is considered acceptable for a jet engine to ingest without damage. On 21 April, the [[Civil Aviation Authority|CAA]] in conjunction with engine manufacturers, set new guidelines<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn18802-engine-stripdowns-establish-safe-volcanic-ash-levels.html |title=Engine strip-downs establish safe volcanic ash levels – tech – 21 April 2010 |publisher=New Scientist |accessdate=21 June 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100512180225/http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn18802-engine-stripdowns-establish-safe-volcanic-ash-levels.html |archivedate=12 May 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> which allowed aircraft to fly when there are levels of volcanic ash between 200 and 2000 microgrammes of ash per cubic metre. These levels were declared by governments, aircraft manufacturers, and airlines not to have safety implications if appropriate maintenance and ash inspection procedures were followed.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8634276.stm Was the flight ban necessary?] BBC News, 21 April 2010</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8654559.stm Volcano ash flight ban 'might have ended sooner'] BBC News, 3 May 2010</ref>
From noon 18 May, the CAA further revised the safe limit upwards to 4 milligrams per cubic metre of air space.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8685913.stm |title=Volcanic ash cloud restrictions lifted at UK airports |publisher=BBC News |date=17 May 2010 |accessdate=21 June 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111013042117/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8685913.stm| archivedate=13 October 2011<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Any airspace in which the ash density exceeds this limit is categorised as a [[no fly zone]].
To minimise the level of further disruption that this and other volcanic eruptions could cause, the [[Civil Aviation Authority|CAA]] announced the creation of a new category of restricted airspace called a [[Time Limited Zone]] (TLZ).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/7/Letter%20to%20NSAs%20re%20Volcanic%20Ash-%20Creation%20of%20TLZ.pdf |title=Letter|accessdate=2010-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522102951/http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/7/Letter%20to%20NSAs%20re%20Volcanic%20Ash-%20Creation%20of%20TLZ.pdf |archivedate=22 May 2010 }}</ref> Airspace categorised as TLZ is similar to airspace experiencing severe weather in that the restrictions are expected to be of a short duration; however, the key difference with TLZ airspace is that airlines must produce certificates of compliance in order for their aircraft to enter these areas. [[Flybe]] was the first airline to conform to these regulations and their aircraft will be permitted to enter airspace in which the ash density is between 2 mg and 4 mg per cubic metre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Volcano-Ash-New-Time-Limited-Zone-Introduced-To-Reduce-Flight-Restrictions-Due-To-Ash-Cloud/Article/201005315633952?f=rss |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713045639/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Volcano-Ash-New-Time-Limited-Zone-Introduced-To-Reduce-Flight-Restrictions-Due-To-Ash-Cloud/Article/201005315633952?f=rss |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 July 2012 |title=Volcano Ash: New Time Limited Zone Introduced To Reduce Flight Restrictions Due To Ash Cloud | UK News | Sky News |publisher=News.sky.com |accessdate=21 June 2010 }}</ref>
==Airspace restrictions in Europe== {{externalvideo |topic=Flight video; variations of traffic due to ash cloud|align=right |video1=[http://vimeo.com/11205494 Radar animation]}} [[File:Travel crisis in Europe 2010.png|thumb|Airspace completely (red) or partially (orange) closed to IFR traffic on 18 April 2010]] [[File:Disruptions at Leeds Bradford Airport during the eruptions of Eyjafjallajökull.jpg|thumb|Flight disruptions at [[Leeds Bradford International Airport]] during the eruptions.]]
[[File:Flights18April2010.png|thumb|Some flights from [[Oslo]] operating and over [[Italy]] by the morning of 18 April 2010.]] [[File:Flights19April2010.png|thumb|Flights returning to most of mainland Europe on 19 April 2010. Note that no data is available for much of France and some other areas.]] [[File:Flights20April2010.png|thumb|Flights apparently operating to all of Europe on 20 April 2010. No data available for much of France and some other areas.]] Under international regulations, all scheduled passenger flights operate under the [[instrument flight rules]] (IFR) which requires clearance to be obtained from [[air traffic control]]. From 14 April onwards, the [[controlled airspace]] was closed in several European countries and no IFR clearances were granted.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} The airspace of Iceland itself was hardly disrupted in this period (although a change in the wind direction on 23 April caused the main airport to be closed).{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
By 23 April, the restrictions were lifted over much of Europe through the introduction of new guidelines on volcanic ash density. After this date there were sporadic closures from time to time, notably in the UK, Ireland, and Iceland, but not a blanket shutdown.
{| class="wikitable" |- |'''Country''' || '''Restrictions imposed''' |- | {{AUT}} || On 16 April, [[Austro Control]] ceased air activities at airports in both [[Vienna]] and [[Linz]]; [[Salzburg]] and [[Innsbruck]] stopped flights at 20:00 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]]; and [[Graz]] and [[Klagenfurt]] followed at 23:00 CEST. At 00:30 on 18 April, all Austrian airports were closed until 18:00.{{Failed verification|reason=cite does say this, reword or better cite needed|date=April 2010}}<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9F49IT80.htm Austria starts closing airspace due to volcano ash] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023213142/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9F49IT80.htm |date=23 October 2012 }} ''Business Week'', 16 April 2010</ref> The Austria Press Agency reported that permission to resume takeoffs and landings took effect at 05:00 local time (0300 UTC) Monday but that it was unclear whether the airspace would remain open all day.<ref>[http://www.ajc.com/business/austria-reopens-airspace-many-472604.html Germany lets Lufthansa fly 15,000 back home] ajc.com, 19 April 2010</ref> |- | {{BLR}} || On Saturday 17 April, the airspace over Belarus was closed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2010/04/17/close/|title=Белоруссия полностью закрыла воздушное пространство|author=|date=|website=lenta.ru|accessdate=6 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072720/http://lenta.ru/news/2010/04/17/close/|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |- | {{BEL}} || Belgium's airspace closed at 16:30 CEST on 15 April. It remained closed until 08:00 CEST on Tuesday 20 April.<ref>[http://www.deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/binnenland/100419_eerste_vluchten Morgen gedeeltelijke hervatting vliegverkeer]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''De Redactie'', 19 April 2010</ref> |- | {{BIH}} || The airspace over Bosnia and Herzegovina was closed to traffic from 08:00 CEST until midnight (00:00 CEST) on 17 April.<ref>[http://news.ph.msn.com/business/article.aspx?cp-documentid=4034696 Bosnia closes airspace to 2200 GMT: official] ''Agence France-Presse'' – MSN News, 17 April 2010</ref> |- | {{BUL}} || On Sunday 18 April, all Bulgarian airports were closed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.ibox.bg/news/id_1962474609|title=Небето над България – блокирано|publisher=News.bg|date=18 April 2010|accessdate=18 April 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420230825/http://news.ibox.bg/news/id_1962474609|archivedate=20 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, at 14:00 local time the airports in [[Sofia]] and [[Plovdiv]] were open.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnes.bg/stranata/2010/04/18/otvoriha-letishte-sofiia-i-plovdiv.89558 |title=Отвориха летище София и Пловдив |publisher=Dnes.bg |date=10 February 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421040345/http://www.dnes.bg/stranata/2010/04/18/otvoriha-letishte-sofiia-i-plovdiv.89558| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{CRO}} || At 02:00 CET on 17 April, the air space over northern Croatia was closed, including [[Zagreb]]. At 08:00 [[Central European Time|CET]] the airports at [[Pula]], [[Rijeka]], [[Zadar]], and [[Lošinj]] were closed.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jutarnji.hr/vulkanski-oblak-nad-sjeverom-hrvatske-obustavio-zracni-promet/723616/ |title=Vulkanski oblak nad sjeverom Hrvatske obustavio zračni promet |publisher=Jutarnji.hr |date=13 April 2010 |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418235108/http://www.jutarnji.hr/vulkanski-oblak-nad-sjeverom-hrvatske-obustavio-zracni-promet/723616/| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>{{Clarify|date=April 2010|reason=ensure cite states airports actually closed, or reword}} |- | {{DNK}} || [[Naviair]], the state-owned company controlling Danish airspace, announced that Denmark's airspace would close at 16:00 UTC on 15 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE63E12820100415?type=marketsNews |title=Denmark plans to close airspace due volcanic ash |publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=15 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/678RofZf3?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/04/15/denmark-airspace-idUSLDE63E12820100415?type=marketsNews |archivedate=23 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, Naviair assessed that it is safe to fly through airspace in high altitude – {{convert|35500|ft}}. This means that aircraft on a route such as Tokyo to New York can fly over Denmark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.berlingske.dk/danmark/danske-lufthavne-lukket-til-tirsdag-morgen |title=Danske lufthavne lukket til tirsdag eftermiddag – Danmark |publisher=Berlingske|date=19 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420230614/http://www.berlingske.dk/danmark/danske-lufthavne-lukket-til-tirsdag-morgen| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Danish airspace will be closed until 02:00 on 21 April.<ref>[http://jp.dk/indland/article2043725.ece Danske lufthavne lukket hele dagen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100423033505/http://jp.dk/indland/article2043725.ece |date=23 April 2010 }} jp.dk</ref> |- | {{EST}} || On 15 April [[Estonian Air]] flights from [[Tallinn]] to [[Oslo]], Copenhagen, and London were cancelled due to airspace closures in [[Norway]], Denmark, and the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tarbija24.ee/?id=250484 |title=Estonian Air tühistas Kopenhaageni, Oslo ja Londoni lennud|trans-title=Estonian Air withdrew Copenhagen, Oslo and London flights |publisher=Tarbija24|language=Estonian |date=15 April 2010|accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418044725/http://www.tarbija24.ee/?id=250484| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} [https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=et&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tarbija24.ee%2F%3Fid%3D250484 Translate]</ref> As the ash cloud spread over Estonia on the night of 16 April, all flights were cancelled due to closure of airspace in [[Estonia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.postimees.ee/?id=250706 |title=Enamik lende Tallinna lennujaamas on tühistatud |publisher=Postimees |date=16 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/678Sv7glV?url=http://www.postimees.ee/250706/enamik-lende-tallinna-lennujaamas-on-tuhistatud/ |archivedate=23 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Estonian airspace was partly opened in the evening of 19 April and completely late evening on 20 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tallinn-airport.ee/eng/news/?newsID=5676 |title=Tallinn Airport airspace is open for traffic |publisher=Tallinn Airport |date=20 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720131159/http://www.tallinn-airport.ee/eng/news/?newsID=5676 |archivedate=20 July 2011 }}</ref> |- | {{FIN}} || Finland closed its airspace at 00:00 [[Eastern European Summer Time|EEST]] on 16 April, having previously closed northern, western, and central parts of its airspace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finavia.fi/home_light/news_light?id=2534577 |title=Disruption in air traffic due to volcanic eruption in Iceland |publisher=Finavia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420121117/http://www.finavia.fi/home_light/news_light?id=2534577 |archivedate=20 April 2010 }}</ref> On 19 April a gap formed in the ash cloud over Finland, and [[Finavia]] lifted flight restrictions at the airports of [[Helsinki-Vantaa]], [[Turku Airport|Turku]], and [[Tampere–Pirkkala Airport|Tampere-Pirkkala]] in the afternoon. During the five hours that Helsinki-Vantaa airport was open, there were a total of ten flights either arriving or departing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Finnish+airspace+opened+briefly+on+Monday/1135256255269|title=Finnish airspace opened briefly on Monday|publisher=Helsingin Sanomat|date=20 April 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426014924/http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Finnish+airspace+opened+briefly+on+Monday/1135256255269|archivedate=26 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 20 April the upper airspace was opened at {{convert|9500|m}} altitude to international overflights above the occurrence of the ash.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finavia.fi/home_light/news_light?id=2571995 |title=Overflights are allowed in 9500 meters altitude |publisher=Finavia }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On 21 April, Helsinki-Vantaa Airport's air traffic control services are open and other airport services, like terminal services, are returning to normal by 12.00 noon. The airport was closed again at 3 pm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finavia.fi/home_light/news_light?id=2575644 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120803045150/http://www.finavia.fi/home_light/news_light?id=2575644 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-03 |title=Helsinki Airport airspace is open for traffic |publisher=Finavia }}</ref> On 22 April, Helsinki-Vantaa Airport was opened around 3 pm, and was expected to remain open at least 24 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finavia.fi/home_light/news_light?id=2592950 |title=Helsinki Airport opened for air traffic |publisher=Finavia }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> |- | {{FRA}} || At 23:00 UTC+02 on 15 April 24 airports, including [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]], were closed.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2010/04/15/general-industrials-eu-iceland-volcano_7517314.html |title=Main Paris airport closing within hours due to ash |publisher=[[Forbes]].com |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=19 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418204841/http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2010/04/15/general-industrials-eu-iceland-volcano_7517314.html| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 17 April, the [[Direction Générale de l'Aviation Civile]] extended the suspension to 35 airports, including all Paris airports, until 08:00 UTC+2 on Monday 19 April.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.europe1.fr/France/Pas-d-avion-dans-le-nord-jusqu-a-lundi-176430/ |title=France : Pas d'avion dans le nord jusqu'à lundi |publisher=Europe1 |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420183240/http://www.europe1.fr/France/Pas-d-avion-dans-le-nord-jusqu-a-lundi-176430/| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 18 April, the closure of the Paris airports was extended to at least 08:00 UTC+2 on Tuesday 20 April.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.aeroportsdeparis.fr/ADP/fr-FR/Passagers/Actualites/Actu.htm |title=actu – Aéroports de Paris |publisher=Aeroports de Paris|accessdate=18 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420001212/http://www.aeroportsdeparis.fr/ADP/fr-FR/Passagers/Actualites/Actu.htm| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{DEU}} || On 16 April, all international airports in Germany were closed.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/318858,extra-ash-to-ground-planes-in-germany-belgium-netherlands.html |title=EXTRA: Ash to ground planes in Germany, Belgium, Netherlands |publisher=Earth Times|accessdate=15 April 2010}}</ref> The complete airspace was opened again for IFR and VFR at 11:00 CEST on 21 April.<ref>{{cite web |author=Deutsche Flugsicherung |url=http://www.dfs.de/dfs/internet_2008/module/presse/deutsch/presse/presseinformation/2010/behinderungen_im_flugverkehr_xi_21_4/index.html |title=Deutscher Luftraum wird für IFR-Flüge freigegeben / Ab 11 Uhr keine Beschränkungen mehr |publisher=Deutsche Flugsicherung |date=21 April 2010 |accessdate=21 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424055020/http://www.dfs.de/dfs/internet_2008/module/presse/deutsch/presse/presseinformation/2010/behinderungen_im_flugverkehr_xi_21_4/index.html |archivedate=24 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | {{HUN}} || Hungary's airspace was closed at 19:00 CEST on 16 April.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://index.hu/kulfold/2010/04/16/meghosszabbitottak_a_brit_legterzarlatot |title=Este hétkor lezárják a magyar légteret |publisher=Index.hu |accessdate=16 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100419123254/http://index.hu/kulfold/2010/04/16/meghosszabbitottak_a_brit_legterzarlatot| archivedate= 19 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no|language=hu}}</ref> It remained closed until 10:00 UTC on Monday 19 April.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://index.hu/belfold/2010/04/19/felettunk_mar_szallhatnak_a_repulok/ |title=Újra megnyitották a magyar légteret |publisher=Index.hu |date=19 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421023117/http://index.hu/belfold/2010/04/19/felettunk_mar_szallhatnak_a_repulok/| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no|language=hu}}</ref> <!-- Note: Local time in Hungary at this time of the year is UTC+02, so two hours must be subtracted from times given in local news! --> |- | {{ISL}} || On 22 April, the Keflavik airport, which serves as the main entry point for International flights to Iceland, closed due to ash.<ref>[http://www.icelandair.us/information/media/newslist/announcement/item430280/FLIGHT_DISRUPTIONS_DUE_TO_VOLCANIC_ACTIVITY_-_More_Here/ FLIGHT DISRUPTIONS DUE TO VOLCANIC ACTIVITY IN ICELAND] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424055436/http://www.icelandair.us/information/media/newslist/announcement/item430280/FLIGHT_DISRUPTIONS_DUE_TO_VOLCANIC_ACTIVITY_-_More_Here/ |date=24 April 2010 }} Iceland Air, 14 May 2010</ref> |- | {{IRL}} || On 15 April, the [[Irish Aviation Authority]] announced restrictions on flying in Irish airspace until {{nowrap|06:00 IST}} on Friday 16 April at the earliest<ref name=rte15april2010>{{cite news|title=Cork, Shannon restrictions lifted |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0415/travel.html |work=[[RTÉ News and Current Affairs|RTÉ News]] |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=19 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418175749/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0415/travel.html |archivedate=18 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Restrictions were lifted on flights to and from [[Cork (city)|Cork]], [[Shannon Airport|Shannon]], and some regional airports by the day's end but restrictions remained at [[Dublin]] until {{Nowrap|11:00 UTC+1}}.<ref name=rte15april2010/>
The government's emergency planning taskforce, which included several government departments, [[Garda Síochána|An Garda Síochána]], [[Met Éireann]], the [[Irish Aviation Authority]] (IAA), and Dublin Airport Authority (DAA), met on the evening of 15 April to discuss the emergency.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0415/breaking2.html Irish flights are grounded as Icelandic ash shuts airspace] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101008014207/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0415/breaking2.html |date=8 October 2010 }} [[The Irish Times]], 15 April 2010</ref> The taskforce had met at the National Emergency Co-ordinating Centre on five further occasions by the morning of 20 April 2010.<ref>[http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=35966&locID=1.2.&pagename=news New ash cloud scuppers plan to open skies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314040523/http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=35966&locID=1.2.&pagename=news |date=14 March 2012 }} TV3, 20 April 2010</ref>
On 16 April, Irish air space was reopened for domestic flights from {{nowrap|10:00 IST}} and westward transatlantic flights resumed from Dublin:<ref name=rte16april2010>[http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0416/travel.html Irish airspace restrictions lifted] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418020647/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0416/travel.html |date=18 April 2010 }} RTÉ News, 16 April 2010</ref> Irish flights which were scheduled to fly eastwards over the United Kingdom and continental European airspace remained grounded.<ref name=rte16april2010/><ref name=rte16april2010/>
On 17 April, the ash spread to most of Ireland, and all airspace was closed until 18:00 UTC+01, and subsequently extended until 18:00 UTC+01 on Monday 19 April.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.iaa.ie/index.jsp?p=93&n=96&a=868| title= Irish Airspace restrictions extended to 1800 Monday 19th April 2010| publisher= Irish Aviation Authority| accessdate= 19 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421032625/http://www.iaa.ie/index.jsp?p=93&n=96&a=868| archivedate= 21 April 2010| deadurl= yes| df= dmy-all}}</ref>
On Monday 19 April, the country's aviation chief warned that Dublin was "damned" and would be shut off to the rest of the world until Friday 23 April.<ref>[http://www.herald.ie/national-news/dublin-in-the-eye-of-storm-2143342.html Dublin in the eye of storm] ''Evening Herald'', 19 April 2010</ref> On Tuesday 20 April, it was reported that at least 30,000 Irish people were still stranded abroad, unable to get home.<ref>[http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/30000-irish-people-stranded-abroad-454632.html 30,000 Irish people stranded abroad] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614041831/http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/30000-irish-people-stranded-abroad-454632.html |date=14 June 2011 }} BreakingNews.ie, 20 April 2010</ref> Those who were at home were opting for "staycations", as Irish holidaymakers swapped [[Barcelona]] for [[Ballybunion]] in a boost for domestic tourism.<ref>[http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/tourism-up-as-ash-cloud-boosts-staycations-454676.html#ixzz0lfFjqyDy Tourism up as ash cloud boosts staycations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614041937/http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/tourism-up-as-ash-cloud-boosts-staycations-454676.html |date=14 June 2011 }} BreakingNews.ie, 20 April 2010</ref>
It had been anticipated that Irish air space would re-open for limited flights from 05:00 UTC+1 on 20 April; however, the volcanic ash cloud made this impossible. It was expected that normal flights will resume from Friday, 23 April, due to the backlog of flights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0419/travelupdates.html |title=RTÉ News: Travel Updates – Monday, 19 April |publisher=RTÉ.ie |date=19 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421020327/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0419/travelupdates.html| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Shannon Airport opened at 13:00 UTC+1 on 20 April (not for departing commercial flights) but Cork Airport and Dublin Airport remained closed.<ref>[http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Shannon-Airport-restrictions-lifted.6238666.jp Shannon Airport restrictions lifted] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100423112303/http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Shannon-Airport-restrictions-lifted.6238666.jp |date=23 April 2010 }} ''Limerick Leader'', 20 April 2010.</ref>
On 20 April at 21:00 UTC+1 Irish airspace fully re-opened, but air travellers were advised to contact their airline. It was expected that normal flights would resume on Friday 23 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0420/travelupdates.html |title=RTÉ News: Travel Updates – Tuesday, 20 April |publisher=RTÉ.ie |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100422035253/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0420/travelupdates.html| archivedate= 22 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> A statement from the [[Irish Aviation Authority]] said "[it] is expected that flights tomorrow [21 April] will focus on positioning aircraft and crews and full service by the airlines may take up to three days to recover. Passengers should consult airline websites before travelling to the airport for flights."<ref name=IrishResume>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8658613.stm |title=Irish flights resume after ash cloud threat lifts |publisher=BBC News|date=20 April 2010|accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100505212338/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8658613.stm| archivedate= 5 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 4 May, Irish airspace closed from 07:00 to 13:00 IST. The IAA said the decision was based on information from the Volcanic Ash Advice Centre (VAAC). The no fly zone affected Dublin, Shannon, Galway, Sligo, Ireland West (Knock), Donegal, Cork, and Kerry.<ref name=IrishResume/> At 13:00 UTC+1 Irish airspace fully re-opened. However further closures and cancellations occurred the next day, on 5 May. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0505/travelupdates.html |title= Live – Travel Updates 5 May 2010|publisher=[[RTÉ News]] |date=5 May 2010|accessdate=5 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100506035631/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0505/travelupdates.html| archivedate= 6 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{ITA}} || [[Ente Nazionale per l'Aviazione Civile]] closed the airspace over [[Northern Italy]] for 17 April, excluding emergency flights and flights flying over {{convert|35000|ft|m}},<ref name="skytg01">{{cite web |url= http://tg24.sky.it/tg24/cronaca/2010/04/16/aeroporti_italia_voli_vulcano_islanda.html |title=Nube di cenere, stop ai voli nel Nord Italia fino alle 20 |language=Italian |date=17 April 2010 |publisher=[[SKY TG24]] |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100419182132/http://tg24.sky.it/tg24/cronaca/2010/04/16/aeroporti_italia_voli_vulcano_islanda.html| archivedate= 19 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> from {{nowrap|06:00 CEST}} until {{nowrap|14:00 CEST}}.<ref name="agi01">{{cite web|url=http://www.agi.it/english-version/italy/elenco-notizie/201004162253-cro-ren1167-art.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110629132909/http://www.agi.it/english-version/italy/elenco-notizie/201004162253-cro-ren1167-art.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 June 2011 |title=Iceland: Italian northern air space off from 6 am TO 2 pm |date=16 April 2010 |work=[[Agenzia Giornalistica Italia|AGI]] |accessdate=17 April 2010 }}</ref> The closure was later extended to {{nowrap|08:00 UTC+02}} on Monday 19 April.<ref name="corsera02"/>
Over 198 flights at the Rome airports were cancelled, 436 at the [[Milan]] airports, 104 at [[Naples]], and 43 at [[Catania]].<ref name="corsera02">{{cite web |url= http://www.corriere.it/cronache/10_aprile_17/italia-traffico-aereo-bloccato_d041118a-49fa-11df-8f1a-00144f02aabe.shtml |title=Vulcano Islanda, la nube arriva in Italia Al Nord stop ai voli fino a lunedì |language=Italian |date=17 April 2010 |work=Corriere della Sera |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420075148/http://www.corriere.it/cronache/10_aprile_17/italia-traffico-aereo-bloccato_d041118a-49fa-11df-8f1a-00144f02aabe.shtml| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="corsera01">{{cite web |url= http://www.corriere.it/cronache/10_aprile_17/italia-traffico-aereo-bloccato_d041118a-49fa-11df-8f1a-00144f02aabe.shtml |title=Traffico aereo: è caos anche in Italia |language=Italian |date=17 April 2010 |work=Corriere della Sera |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420075148/http://www.corriere.it/cronache/10_aprile_17/italia-traffico-aereo-bloccato_d041118a-49fa-11df-8f1a-00144f02aabe.shtml| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Kosovo}} || Kosovo closed its airspace at 00:00 UTC+02 on 18 April, cutting air access to [[Pristina]]. It was to reopen at 14:00 UTC+02 on 18 April.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.telegrafi.com/?id=46&a=5137 |title=Aeroporti i Prishtinës mbyllet në mesnatë |language=Albanian |date=18 April 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2010 |publisher=Telegrafi |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/678S0Nt82?url=http://www.telegrafi.com/?id=46 |archivedate=23 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=lv&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.apollo.lv%2Fportal%2Fnews%2Farticles%2F200338 Translate]</ref> It is to remain closed until at least 06:00 UTC on 19 April, but would probably remain closed until 22 April.<ref name=tvnet327387>{{cite web|title=Latvijas gaisa telpu slēgs līdz pirmdienas pulksten <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} |- | {{LUX}} || [[Luxembourg Airport]] was closed for virtually all flights on 16 April and remained closed at least until the evening of 18 April.<ref name=wortlu85156>{{cite news|url=http://www.wort.lu/wort/web/letzebuerg/artikel/85156/am-freitagmorgen-geht-am-flughafen-nicht-viel.php |title=Keine Flüge vor 14 Uhr|trans-title=No flights 14 hours|work=[[Luxemburger Wort]]|language=de|accessdate=19 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418213852/http://www.wort.lu/wort/web/letzebuerg/artikel/85156/am-freitagmorgen-geht-am-flughafen-nicht-viel.php| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125233729/http://www.lux-airport.lu/2008/index.php?lang=fr&fidlanguage=2 |date=25 January 2010 }} {{fr icon}} lux-Airport. Retrieved 18 April 2010.</ref> |- | {{NLD}} || Dutch airspace closed at 17:00 UTC on 15 April and remained closed until 20:00 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] on 19 April. They restarted flights after this time, starting with 4 [[KLM]] flights to [[Dubai]], New York, Toronto, and Shanghai.<ref name="nunl">{{cite news|title=Luchtruim dicht om aswolk|trans-title=Ash plume to close airspace|url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/2226492/schiphol-gaat-definitief-dicht.html|language=nl|work=[[NU.nl]]|date=15 April 2010|accessdate=19 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418175720/http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/2226492/schiphol-gaat-definitief-dicht.html| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=nl&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nu.nl%2Fbinnenland%2F2226492%2Fluchtruim-dicht-aswolk.html Translate]</ref><ref>{{nl icon}} [http://www.klm.com/travel/gb_en/prepare_for_travel/up_to_date/flight_update/index.htm Flight disruptions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419151121/http://www.klm.com/travel/gb_en/prepare_for_travel/up_to_date/flight_update/index.htm |date=19 April 2010 }}, KLM, 19 April 2010</ref><ref name="NOS151769">{{cite news|language=nl|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/151769-vanavond-eerste-vluchten-schiphol.html|title= Vanavond Eerste vluchten Schiphol vertrokken|trans-title=First flights departed Schiphol|work=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]]|date=19 April 2010|accessdate=19 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100422200118/http://nos.nl/artikel/151769-vanavond-eerste-vluchten-schiphol.html| archivedate= 22 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} [https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=nl&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fnos.nl%2Fartikel%2F151769-vanavond-eerste-vluchten-schiphol.html Translate]</ref> |- | {{NOR}} || Air travel was suspended from 14 April. Airports throughout [[Nord-Trøndelag]], [[Nordland]], [[Troms]], and [[Finnmark]] were re-opened at times, as those areas were least affected by the ash: the largest of these, [[Trondheim Airport, Værnes|Trondheim]], was opened for six hours on 16 April. The total closure of Norwegian airspace included the 21 [[search and rescue]] and medical aircraft and helicopters in the country. The health authorities stated that the challenges faced were unprecedented in modern history, and ambulances and medical personnel were moved north and out of cities to decentralise the service and replace the lost aerial transport.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.regjeringen.no/nb/dep/hod/pressesenter/pressemeldinger/2010/Helsevesenet-far-utvidede-fullmakter.html?id=600860 |title=Helsevesenet får utvidede fullmakter |publisher=The Norwegian Government |language=Norwegian |date=16 April 2010 |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421062736/http://www.regjeringen.no/nb/dep/hod/pressesenter/pressemeldinger/2010/Helsevesenet-far-utvidede-fullmakter.html?id=600860| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The air space caused most of the [[oil platform]]s in the [[North Sea]] to not be able to fly in new personnel, causing existing crews to have to work until 18 April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ba.no/nyheter/vulkanskyen/article5076651.ece |title=I luften igjen |work=[[Bergensavisen]] |language=Norwegian |date=18 April 2010 |last=Langeland |first=Solfrid Torvund |accessdate=22 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421041855/http://www.ba.no/nyheter/vulkanskyen/article5076651.ece| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{POL}} || Poland closed the northern part of its airspace at 18:00 UTC on 15 April. On 16 April its whole airspace was shut down.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wiadomosci.wp.pl/kat,1342,title,Zamknieta-przestrzen-powietrzna-nad-polnocna-Polska,wid,12176191,wiadomosc.html |title=Zamknięta przestrzeń powietrzna nad północną Polską |publisher=Wirtualna Polska |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=16 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418215532/http://wiadomosci.wp.pl/kat%2C1342%2Ctitle%2CZamknieta-przestrzen-powietrzna-nad-polnocna-Polska%2Cwid%2C12176191%2Cwiadomosc.html |archivedate=18 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The disruption affected the [[Death and state funeral of Lech Kaczyński and Maria Kaczyńska|funeral]] for the Polish president [[Lech Kaczyński]], his wife [[Maria Kaczyńska|Maria]], and the other victims who died in an [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|air crash]] earlier in April. Family members decided not to postpone the ceremony, resulting in other countries' dignitaries being unable to attend. |- | {{POR}} || Portugal's [[Institute of Meteorology]] (IM) announced on Tuesday 20 April that the cloud of volcanic ash entered the Portuguese airspace controlled by the Azorean island of Santa Maria, in an area still far from the national territory, and that the affected area was "very small".<ref name="google1">{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fdiario.iol.pt%2Fsociedade%2Fvoo-aeroporto-lisboa-porto-faro-tvi24%2F1156398-4071.html |title= 83 canceled flights on Tuesday |publisher=PortugalDiário|date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010}}</ref> For the most part, only flights to countries with closed airspaces were cancelled forcing numerous members of the government (including the president) who were away to return to the country by car from the UK, Austria, and Belgium.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://tudoglobal.com/blog/editorias/mundo/41811/70-dos-voos-na-europa-foram-cancelados.html |title=70-dos-voos-na-europa-foram-cancelados|publisher=Tudo Global|date=19 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100425060908/http://tudoglobal.com/blog/editorias/mundo/41811/70-dos-voos-na-europa-foram-cancelados.html| archivedate= 25 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> however several flights to the U.S. and elsewhere were also cancelled because of the unavailability of planes coming from other parts of Europe or carriers that required the planes to stop in their countries, such as Germany or France.<ref name="google1"/> |- | {{ROU}} || Romania closed the northwestern part of its airspace at 00:00 local time ([[UTC+03]]) on 17 April, including [[Oradea]], [[Satu Mare]], [[Baia Mare]], [[Cluj-Napoca]], [[Sibiu]], and [[Timişoara]] airports. The two [[Bucharest]] airports were also closed. Romania's entire airspace closed at 18:00 local time ([[UTC+03]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/english/romania-closes-entire-airspace-as-volcanic-ash-cloud-approaches-5924212|title=Romania Closes Entire Airspace As Volcanic Ash Cloud Approaches|publisher=[[Mediafax]]|date=17 April 2010|accessdate=17 April 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/678Saa9Ni?url=http://www.mediafax.ro/english/romania-closes-entire-airspace-as-volcanic-ash-cloud-approaches-5924212|archivedate=23 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> on 17 April until at least 12:00 on 19 April. On 20 April Timisoara, Otopeni, Băneasa, Craiova, Cluj-Napoca, Sibiu, Oradea, Satu Mare, and Baia Mare airports reopened.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adevarul.ro/actualitate/eveniment/curse_anulate-nor_vulcanic_0_244775530.html |title=Spaţiul aerian al României e închis/ Lista curselor anulate |publisher=Adevarul.ro |accessdate=17 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522102453/http://www.adevarul.ro/actualitate/eveniment/curse_anulate-nor_vulcanic_0_244775530.html |archivedate=22 May 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> |- | {{SRB}}<br />{{MNE}}<br />{{BIH}} || Air Traffic Services Agency of Serbia and Montenegro, shut down all traffic over [[Serbia]], Montenegro, part of international waters of the [[Adriatic Sea]], and the upper airspace of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] that it controls, at 14:00 UTC, 17 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2010&mm=04&dd=17&nav_category=9&nav_id=425039 |title=Vazdušni prostor zatvoren u 16h |publisher=B92.net |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420063053/http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2010&mm=04&dd=17&nav_category=9&nav_id=425039| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The airspace was reopened at 22:00 UTC, 18 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2010&mm=04&dd=19&nav_category=12&nav_id=425293 |title=Avio-saobraćaj donekle uspostavljen |publisher=B92.net |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420081844/http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2010&mm=04&dd=19&nav_category=12&nav_id=425293| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{SVK}} || Slovakia's airspace was closed at 15:00 UTC on 16 April.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://spectator.sme.sk/articles/view/38562/10/slovakia_closes_its_airspace.html |title=Slovakia closes its airspace |work=The Spectator |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421081936/http://spectator.sme.sk/articles/view/38562/10/slovakia_closes_its_airspace.html| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{SVN}} || The [[Transport Ministry of Slovenia|Transport Ministry]] closed the airspace to the north of the [[46th parallel north|46th parallel]] up to {{convert|35500|ft}} at 22:00 UTC on 16 April, and over the entire country at 06:00 UTC on 17 April. The closure lasted until 19:10 UTC on 18 April.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/novice/zaprtje-zracnega-prostora-republike-slovenije |title=Zaprtje zračnega prostora Republike https://web.archive.org/web/20100422005542/http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/novice/zaprtje-zracnega-prostora-republike-slovenije| archivedate= 22 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/novice/zacasno-popolno-odprtje-zracnega-prostora-v-rs |title=Začasno popolno odprtje zračnega prostora v RS |language=Slovenian |trans-title=Temporary full opening of the airspace in the Republic of Slovenia |publisher=Sloveniacontrol.si |date=18 April 2010 |accessdate=19 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002080451/http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/novice/zacasno-popolno-odprtje-zracnega-prostora-v-rs |archivedate=2 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It was the first closure of Slovenian airspace since the [[Ten-Day War]] in 1991.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://24ur.com/novice/svet/foto-letala-se-kar-odpovedujejo-lete.html |title=Slovenija zapira zračni
