https://web.archive.org/web/20100418025812/http://24ur.com/novice/svet/foto-letala-se-kar-odpovedujejo-lete.html| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 03:00 UTC on 20 April, the airspace was closed again up to {{convert|20500|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/novice/ponovno-zaprtje-zracnega-prostora-republike-slovenije |title=Zaprtje zračnega prostora Republike Slovenije |language=Slovenian |trans-title=Closure of the airspace of the Republic of Slovenia |publisher=Sloveniacontrol.si |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110922103657/http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/novice/ponovno-zaprtje-zracnega-prostora-republike-slovenije |archivedate=22 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 07:00 UTC on 21 April, the airspace was opened again without restrictions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/eng/news/withdraw-of-all-restrictions-to-the-slovenian-airspace |title=Withdraw of all restrictions to the Slovenian airspace |date=21 April 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002080536/http://www.sloveniacontrol.si/eng/news/withdraw-of-all-restrictions-to-the-slovenian-airspace |archivedate=2 October 2011 }}</ref> |- | {{ESP}} ||[[Aena]] closed seven airports in northern Spain at 20:00 UTC+1 on 17 April: they were planned to remain closed until 10:00 on 18 April,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aena.es/csee/Satellite?Language=EN_GB&SiteName=Home&c=Modulo&cid=1237544941761&pagename=Comunes%2FModuloPopUp |title=Alerts – Aena.es – Spanish airports and airspace |publisher=Aena.es |accessdate=17 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422015343/http://www.aena.es/csee/Satellite?Language=EN_GB&SiteName=Home&c=Modulo&cid=1237544941761&pagename=Comunes%2FModuloPopUp |archivedate=22 April 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> but one hour later, at 21:00 UTC+1 they started to operate again. At 08:30 UTC+1 on 18 11 April northern airports were closed, including [[Barcelona]], the country's second largest. At 12:00 UTC+1 two more airports in the [[Balearic Islands]] were closed, including Spain's third largest [[Palma de Mallorca]]. All 13 airports were expected to reopen at 20:00 UTC+1 on 18 April. Other minor airports, not controlled by Aena, were closed as well, although it was thought they could be re-opened at 15:30 UTC+1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aena.es/csee/Satellite?Language=EN_GB&SiteName=Home&c=Modulo&cid=1237544941761&pagename=Comunes/ModuloPopUp |title=Alerts – Aena.es – Spanish airports and airspace (Spanish) |publisher=Aena.es |accessdate=18 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422015343/http://www.aena.es/csee/Satellite?Language=EN_GB&SiteName=Home&c=Modulo&cid=1237544941761&pagename=Comunes%2FModuloPopUp |archivedate=22 April 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> |- | {{SWE}} || Sweden's airspace was closed at 20:00 UTC on 15 April. Airspace north of [[Söderhamn]] was reopened at 16:45 CEST on 18 April.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/SAT008465.htm |title=Sweden to shut airspace due to Iceland volcano |publisher=Reuters Alertnet |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=15 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/678SlswJC?url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/ |archivedate=23 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | {{CHE}} || The Federal Office of Civil Aviation issued a [[NOTAM|notice to airmen]] at 14:15 UTC on 16 April stating that the FIR Switzerland{{Clarify|date=April 2010}} would be closed for [[visual flight rules|visual]] and [[instrument flight rules|instrument]] flight rules operations from 21:59 UTC on 16 April to 12:00 UTC on 19 April.<ref>NOTAM: LSSN-A0182/10</ref> Police, Search and Rescue (SAR) and emergency medical helicopter flights were exempted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bazl.admin.ch/aktuell/medieninformation/00024/index.html?lang=de&msg-id=32655 |title=Aschenwolke: Schweizer Luftraum aus Sicherheitsgründen vorübergehend geschlossen |publisher=BAZL |date=16 April 2010 |accessdate=16 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807153925/http://www.bazl.admin.ch/aktuell/medieninformation/00024/index.html?lang=de |archivedate=7 August 2011 }}</ref> [[Swiss International Air Lines]] informed its customers on 16 April that the airports at [[Zurich]], [[Basel]], Geneva, and [[Lugano]] airports would be closed, and that all flights going to those airports would be cancelled.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swiss.com/web/EN/various/Pages/Breaking_news.aspx |title=Latest Flight Update |publisher=Swiss.com |accessdate=16 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100222230335/http://www.swiss.com/web/EN/various/Pages/Breaking_news.aspx |archivedate=22 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | {{TUR}} || The Directorate General of Civil Aviation closed central-northern national air zones by 13:30 UTC (16:30 UTC+3) on 18 April between flight levels FL200 and FL350 until 09:00 UTC (12:00 UTC+3) on 19 April. All airports, however, remained open.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.shgm.gov.tr/kurumsal.php?page=haberler&id=1&haber_id=1123 |title=Press Release |publisher=Republic of Turkey, Ministry of Transport and Communication, The Directorate General of Civil Aviation |date=18 April 2010 |accessdate=19 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902024545/http://web.shgm.gov.tr/kurumsal.php?page=haberler&id=1&haber_id=1123 |archivedate=2 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | {{UKR}} || The Ministry of Transport closed most national air zones by 00:00 UTC+3 on 17 April: only southern airports remained open. Aircraft from [[Egypt]] and [[Thailand]], bound for [[Kiev]], landed at [[Simferopol]]. All Ukrainian airspace was closed by 15:00 EEST on 17 April.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/events/1067848 |title=Самолеты, летящие в Киев, вынуждены приземляться в Симферополе |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420063430/http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/events/1067848 |archivedate=20 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/events/1067872 |title=Движение воздушного транспорта в Украине полностью прекращено |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420063435/http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/events/1067872 |archivedate=20 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | {{GBR}} || [[Scotland]] was the third region in Europe, after Iceland and Norway, to be affected, with all Scottish airports being closed to [[instrument flight rules|instrument flight rules (IFR)]] operations by 04:00 BST on 15 April. The United Kingdom's controlled airspace was closed to IFR flights at 11:00 UTC (12:00 [[British Summer Time|BST]]) on 15 April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8621848.stm |title=Airports affected by volcanic ash from Iceland|publisher=BBC News |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418202314/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8621848.stm| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, several Icelandair planes flying from Keflavik landed at Glasgow on 16 April.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dalton |first=Alastair |url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/news/-Scots-keep--world.6234203.jp |title=Scots keep world flying in fallout from volcano |work=The Scotsman |accessdate=20 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420065356/http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/news/-Scots-keep--world.6234203.jp| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The last commercial flight to leave British airspace before the lockdown was imposed was a [[Singapore Airlines]] flight (number SQ317) from [[London Heathrow]] airport to [[Singapore Changi]] airport. It was officially scheduled to leave at 11:55 BST but became airborne at 11:32.
There was no restriction on [[visual flight rules]] traffic. [[Royal Air Force]] [[RAF Search and Rescue Force|search and rescue aircraft]] continued to operate as normal, as did flights between [[Land's End Airport|Land's End]] and the [[St Mary's Airport (Isles of Scilly)|Isles of Scilly]] which operate in [[uncontrolled airspace]] at an [[Altitude#Altitude in aviation|altitude]] less than {{convert|3000|ft}}.<ref>[http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Skybus-beats-gloom/story-11384607-detail/story.html "Skybus beats the gloom"]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''[[Western Morning News]]'', 16 April 2010</ref>
There remained no commercial airliners in British airspace until the morning of 16 April, when an [[Air Transat]] flight was given clearance to leave [[Glasgow]] for Toronto.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/796438--hope-for-passengers-flight-arrives-in-toronto-from-glasgow?bn=1 Hope for passengers? Flight arrives in Toronto from Glasgow] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020234815/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/796438--hope-for-passengers-flight-arrives-in-toronto-from-glasgow?bn=1 |date=20 October 2012 }} thestar.com, 16 April 2010</ref>
On the evening of 20 April, it was announced that all the UK's airports would be opened from 22:00 BST.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8633597.stm UK airports set to reopen] BBC News, 20 April 2010</ref>
On 4 May, the airspace over Northern Ireland and the west of Scotland closed from 07:00 to 13:00 UTC+1. The CAA said the decision was based on information from the Volcanic Ash Advice Centre (VAAC). The no fly zone affected both Belfast airports and Derry airport. <ref name=IrishResume/> At 13:00 UTC+1 the airspace over Northern Ireland and Scotland fully re-opened. However, further closures occurred on 5 May. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8661096.stm |title= Scottish, Irish and Northern Irish airports shut by ash |publisher=BBC News |date=5 May 2010|accessdate=5 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100506032139/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8661096.stm| archivedate= 6 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 16 May, the airspace closed over much of the UK from 13:00 until 17 May 07:00 UTC+1. The airports affected were East Midlands, Manchester, Liverpool, Doncaster Sheffield, Humberside, Carlisle, Belfast City, Belfast International, Glasgow Prestwick, those on Scottish islands, and the Isle of Man. London airports remained open most of that period except for a period during the early morning of 17 May. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8685193.stm |title= Volcanic ash closes UK airports |publisher=BBC News |date=16 May 2010|accessdate=16 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100519125918/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8685193.stm| archivedate= 19 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref> {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8685913.stm |title= Ash cloud forces Heathrow and Gatwick airports to close |publisher=BBC News |date=17 May 2010|accessdate=17 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111013042117/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8685913.stm| archivedate=13 October 2011<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |}
==Disruptions outside Europe== Almost every country with an international airport experienced some disruption due to flights to or from Europe being canceled. Outside Europe, Canada, Russia, and Kazakhstan were the only countries to deal with a risk from ash clouds in their airspace.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}}
===Canada=== The Canadian airspace was never closed or restricted because of volcanic ash. Although the UK Met Office map of 21 April<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/aviation/vaac/data/VAG_1271763280.png |title=VAG |accessdate=2010-04-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524182035/http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/aviation/vaac/data/VAG_1271763280.png |archivedate=24 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> shows the ash cloud reaching [[Labrador]], [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]], the [[Canadian Maritimes|Maritime provinces]], far eastern [[Quebec]], and the [[Gulf of St. Lawrence]], concentrations were expected to be sparse.<ref name="Canada ash risk">[https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100419-712515.html?mod=WSJ_World_MIDDLEHeadlinesEurope "Canada Sees 'Low Risk' From Volcanic Ash Drifting West"] ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 20 April 2010</ref>
On Monday, 19 April, the combination of heavy fog with a warning by [[Transport Canada]] and [[Nav Canada]] of a 30% risk of volcanic ash reaching [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]] led to the cancellation of several flights scheduled to leave [[St. John's International Airport]], [[Gander International Airport|Gander]], and [[Deer Lake Regional Airport|Deer Lake]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2010/04/18/nl-volcanic-ash-flights.html "Flights scrapped as Iceland ash heads to N.L."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421012120/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2010/04/18/nl-volcanic-ash-flights.html |date=21 April 2010 }} [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC News]], 19 April 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.cyberpresse.ca/actualites/quebec-canada/national/201004/18/01-4271773-le-nuage-de-cendres-pourrait-atteindre-terre-neuve.php "Le nuage de cendres pourrait atteindre Terre-Neuve"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421033102/http://www.cyberpresse.ca/actualites/quebec-canada/national/201004/18/01-4271773-le-nuage-de-cendres-pourrait-atteindre-terre-neuve.php |date=21 April 2010 }} ''La Presse (Quebec)'', 18 April 2010</ref> Because of the heavy fog, it is unclear if the ash cloud warning was really the cause of the cancellations and delays in [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]], and most flights returned to their normal schedule within the day.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/797429--volcanic-ash-has-no-impact-on-east-coast-flights "Volcanic ash has no impact on East Coast flights"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422021007/http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/797429--volcanic-ash-has-no-impact-on-east-coast-flights |date=22 April 2010 }} ''Toronto Star'', 20 April 2010</ref> [[Air Canada]] said their flights were "subject to some delays due to inclement weather, unrelated to ash cloud."<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/ash-cloud-fears-as-flights-delayed-in-canadian-airspace/article1539013/ "Volcanic cloud fears lift, Canadian airspace remains open"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722150508/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/ash-cloud-fears-as-flights-delayed-in-canadian-airspace/article1539013/ |date=22 July 2010 }} ''The Globe and Mail'', 19 April 2010</ref> On Tuesday, 20 April, two [[Air Canada Jazz]] flights between the [[Magdalen Islands]] and [[Quebec City]] cancelled stop-offs in [[Gaspé, Quebec|Gaspé]] because of ash over the [[Michel-Pouliot Gaspé Airport]].<ref>[http://www.torontosun.com/news/canada/2010/04/19/13643591-qmi.html Ash cloud won't hit Montreal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529020516/http://www.torontosun.com/news/canada/2010/04/19/13643591-qmi.html |date=29 May 2010 }} ''[[Toronto Sun]]'', 20 April 2010</ref>
== Attempts to reopen airspace == [[File:Ash plume from Eyjafjallajokull Volcano over the North Atlantic, 15 April 2010, annotated.jpg|thumb|300px|Ash plume blowing across the North Atlantic on 15 April.]] Most airspace started to close from 15 April. However, in the days following there were brief windows free of the cloud at different locations which were exploited to make a few aircraft movements. There then followed test flights and pressure grew to re-evaluate the criteria for safe levels of ash to fly through.
On 16 April a 30-minute break at [[Manchester]] allowed two flights to land, and one aircraft to be moved to Florida, empty (as there was no time for passengers to board). At [[Glasgow]], an [[Air Transat]] flight to Toronto took off while a [[British Airways]] flight from New York, and a [[Thomas Cook Group|Thomas Cook]] flight from [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]]<ref name=grauniad17>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/apr/16/volcanic-ash-air-travel-europe |title=Volcanic ash keeps flights across Europe grounded |work=The Guardian |date= 17 April 2010|accessdate=20 April 2010| location=London | first=Robert | last=Booth| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100419165437/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/apr/16/volcanic-ash-air-travel-europe| archivedate= 19 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and [[Icelandair]] flights from [[Keflavik]]<ref>[http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/news/-Scots-keep--world.6234203.jp Scots keep world flying in fallout from volcano] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420065356/http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/news/-Scots-keep--world.6234203.jp |date=20 April 2010 }} The Scotsman</ref> landed.
On 17 April 2010, the president of German airline [[Air Berlin]], in an interview with the newspaper [[Bild|Bild am Sonntag]], stated that the risks for flights due to this volcanic haze were nonexistent, because the assessment was based only on a computer simulation produced by the [[VAAC]]. He went on to claim that the [[Luftfahrt-Bundesamt]] closed German airspace without checking the accuracy of these simulations.<ref name="bild01">{{cite web |url=http://www.bild.de/BILD/news/2010/04/17/flugverbot-ueber-europa/berechtigt-oder-skandal-air-berlin-chef-hunold-erhebt-vorwuerfe.html |title=Ist das Flugverbot berechtigt oder ein Skandal? |language=German |date=17 April 2010 |work=[[Bild|Bild am Sonntag]] |accessdate=18 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420162044/http://www.bild.de/BILD/news/2010/04/17/flugverbot-ueber-europa/berechtigt-oder-skandal-air-berlin-chef-hunold-erhebt-vorwuerfe.html| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Spokesmen for [[Lufthansa]] and [[KLM]] stated that during their test flights, required by the [[European Union]], there were no problems with the aircraft.<ref name="agi02">{{cite web|url=http://www.agi.it/news/notizie/201004181016-cro-rt10003-isalnda_presidente_airberlin_rischio_voli_e_bufala_dei_computer |title=Islanda: Presidente Airberlin, Rischio voli è bufala dei computer |language=Italian |date=18 April 2010 |work=[[Agenzia Giornalistica Italia|AGI]] |accessdate=18 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421202048/http://www.agi.it/news/notizie/201004181016-cro-rt10003-isalnda_presidente_airberlin_rischio_voli_e_bufala_dei_computer |archivedate=21 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> On the morning of 17 April [[Lufthansa]] moved 10 aircraft from [[Munich]] to [[Frankfurt]] at low altitude following visual flight rules. There were no problems reported and no sign of damage to the planes.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/0,1518,689573,00.html Überführungsflug landet sicher in Frankfurt] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418235331/http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/0,1518,689573,00.html |date=18 April 2010 }}, Spiegel Online, 17 April 2010</ref> The same day, an Airbus belonging to [[Ural Airlines]] attempted flying below the ash clouds from Moscow to [[Rimini]]. When the airplane was in Austrian airspace, the crew reported being low on fuel and diverted to [[Vienna]], where the airplane landed safely.<ref>[http://avherald.com/h?article=42a3d003&opt=0 Incident: Ural Airlines A321 near Vienna on 17 Apr 2010, fuel emergency], The Aviation Herald, 17 April 2010</ref>
On the morning of 18 April KLM successfully carried out a test flight from [[Amsterdam]] to [[Düsseldorf]] with no problems. Afterwards, seven KLM planes with no passengers returned from Düsseldorf to Amsterdam.<ref>[http://www.luchtvaartnieuws.nl/news/default.asp?cat=al&id=34539 Zeven KLM-toestellen terug uit Düsseldorf]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Luchtvaartnieuws, 18 April 2010</ref> [[Air France]] also performed a test flight from Paris to [[Toulouse]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/europe/20100418-test-flights-begin-travel-remains-seriously-disrupted-icelandic-volcanic-ash |title=Test flights begin, but travel remains seriously disrupted by Icelandic volcanic ash |date=18 April 2010 |work=[[Radio France Internationale|RFI]] |accessdate=18 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421041227/http://www.english.rfi.fr/europe/20100418-test-flights-begin-travel-remains-seriously-disrupted-icelandic-volcanic-ash| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In the evening of 18 April German airspace was partially re-opened for a period of 3 hours allowing a plane of stranded holidaymakers from [[Faro, Portugal|Faro]], Portugal to land at [[Hanover]].<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/reise/deutschland/0,1518,689695,00.html Wirrwarr um Flughafen-Schließungen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421003638/http://www.spiegel.de/reise/deutschland/0,1518,689695,00.html |date=21 April 2010 }}, Spiegel Online, 18 April 2010</ref>
The vice president of the Dutch pilots union said "We are asking the authorities to really have a good look at the situation, because 100 per cent safety does not exist," Mr. Verhagen continued. "It's easy to close down air space because then it's perfectly safe, but at some time you have to resume flights."<ref>[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/apr/18/european-airlines-send-test-flights-despite-ash/ EU: Half of regular flights may operate Monday] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421001620/http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/apr/18/european-airlines-send-test-flights-despite-ash/ |date=21 April 2010 }} Washington Times, 18 April 2010</ref>
In the afternoon of 19 April, German carriers Lufthansa and Air Berlin obtained permission for some flights from and to German airports under [[Visual Flight Rules]]. Lufthansa started sending planes to long-haul destination in order to return stranded passengers later that day.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/0,1518,689875,00.html Flugchaos: Lufthansa und Air Berlin holen Tausende Deutsche zurück] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422115752/http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/0,1518,689875,00.html |date=22 April 2010 }} Spiegel Online, 19 April 2010</ref>
Late on 19 April and early on 20 April, some flights were permitted to take off in northern Europe, including from [[Scotland]] and northern England, but [[Manchester Airport]], that had planned to open on 20 April, remained closed because of a new ash cloud.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.manchesterairport.co.uk/ |title=Manchester Airport update |date=20 April 2010 |publisher=Manchester Airport |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606233820/http://www.manchesterairport.co.uk/ |archivedate=6 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The [[Civil Aviation Authority]] announced that all UK airports would be permitted to open from 2200 on 20 April. Twenty-six British Airways long-haul flights were already in the air and requesting permission to land.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.scotsman.com/news/Travel-latest-Scottish-airspace-to.6238913.jp |title=Travel latest: UK airspace reopens from 10 pm|work=The Scotsman |date=20 April 2010|location=Edinburgh|first=Stephen|last=Emerson}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/5/20100421/tuk-did-ba-brinkmanship-force-no-fly-zon-45dbed5.html |title=BA Brinkmanship |publisher=Yahoo! News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100425011407/http://uk.news.yahoo.com/5/20100421/tuk-did-ba-brinkmanship-force-no-fly-zon-45dbed5.html |archivedate=25 April 2010 }}</ref>
By 20–21 April several airlines confirmed that "air service will be resumed in stages" and started publishing lists of selected flights that were "most likely to be operated" within one single day.<ref>[http://www.lufthansa.com/mediapool/pdf/56/media_813456.pdf?blt_p=DE&blt_l=en&blt_t=Local&blt_e=Content&blt_n=Flight%20operations%20is&blt_z=List%20of%20operating%20fl&blt_c=DE%7Cen%7CLocal%7CContent%7CFlight%20operations%20is%7CList%20of%20operating%20fl Special Timetable of Lufthansa German Airlines for 20APR10] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725090727/http://www.lufthansa.com/mediapool/pdf/56/media_813456.pdf?blt_p=DE&blt_l=en&blt_t=Local&blt_e=Content&blt_n=Flight%20operations%20is&blt_z=List%20of%20operating%20fl&blt_c=DE%7Cen%7CLocal%7CContent%7CFlight%20operations%20is%7CList%20of%20operating%20fl |date=25 July 2011 }} Lufthansa</ref><ref>[http://www.lot.com/Info/EN/aspx/Content_18232.aspx LOT resumes flights] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421042126/http://www.lot.com/Info/en/aspx/Content_18232.aspx |date=21 April 2010 }} LOT</ref> "Effective Thursday, 22 April, Lufthansa will resume normal flight operations and offer you the usual reliability", claimed the airline at 15:30 on 21 April.<ref>[http://www.lufthansa.com/online/portal/lh/de/nonav/local?nodeid=1874371&l=en&cid=18002&blt_p=DE&blt_l=en&blt_t=Homepage&blt_e=Homepage%20-%20Hero&blt_n=Lufthansa%20returns%20to&blt_z=%C2%A0&blt_c=DE |en|Homepage|Homepage%20-%20Hero|Lufthansa%20returns%20to Lufthansa returns to normal flight operations] {{dead link|date=July 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Lufthansa</ref>
==Stranded travelers== The closure of the airspace left five million travelers stranded around the world,<ref>"[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/travel/news/article7101162.ece Volcanic ash grounds Britain for days to come] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418101406/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/travel/news/article7101162.ece |date=18 April 2010 }}" Times Online, 18 April 2010</ref> of which up to a million were British according to [[Association of British Travel Agents|ABTA]].<ref>"[http://www.dailyexpress.co.uk/posts/view/169810/Volcano-ash-Now-a-million-Britons-stranded- Volcanic ash: Now a million Britons stranded]" Daily Express, 17 April 2010</ref><ref>"[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1266568/Volcanic-ash-cloud-100-000-Britons-stranded-Europe-air-traffic-chiefs-extend-lockdown-7am.html One million Britons stranded by ash and food shortages expected: Volcano flight chaos to last until next week] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120723080921/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1266568/Volcanic-ash-cloud-100-000-Britons-stranded-Europe-air-traffic-chiefs-extend-lockdown-7am.html |date=23 July 2012 }}" Mail Online, 17 April 2010</ref> Several thousand passengers were stranded in Asia,<ref>"[http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/thousands-stranded-in-asia-due-to-iceland-volcano/article399511.ece Thousands stranded in Asia due to Iceland volcano] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130223742/http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/thousands-stranded-in-asia-due-to-iceland-volcano/article399511.ece |date=30 January 2016 }}" The Hindu, 17 April 2010</ref> the United States, and Australia.<ref name="QANTAS_cancels">"[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/04/16/2874517.htm Qantas cancels flights as ash smothers Europe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100417093803/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/04/16/2874517.htm |date=17 April 2010 }}" ABC News, 16 April 2010</ref> Disruption was greater than that after the [[September 11 attacks|11 September attacks]], for example:<ref>"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8627720.stm Volcanic ash spreads more travel misery across Europe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420090017/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8627720.stm |date=20 April 2010 }}" BBC News, 18 April 2010</ref>
* The disruption had a significant effect on schools across the United Kingdom because it came at the end of the Easter Holidays and many pupils and teachers were among those stranded abroad.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/8626032.stm|title=Pupils and teachers stranded by volcanic ash drift|date=17 April 2010|first=Angela|last=Harrison}}</ref> * Swedish and Norwegian charter tourists visiting Mallorca, Canary Islands, Cyprus, or Egypt were flown to Barcelona or Athens and then driven back to Sweden and Norway by bus<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barometern.se/nyheter/strandade-turister-bussas-hem(1879316).gm|title=Strandade turister bussas hem|publisher=Barometern Oskarshamns-Tidningen|date=18 April 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420143451/http://www.barometern.se/nyheter/strandade-turister-bussas-hem(1879316).gm|archivedate=20 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> (a total distance of ≈{{convert|3400|km}} from Athens to Oslo by road taking two and a half days without a break).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=ATH:+Athens+International+Airport,+Spata,+19019,+Greece+(Athens+International+Airport)&daddr=Oslo,+Norway&geocode=FeBOQgIdNCRqASHSxp3QT8a8qQ%3BFVw2kgMdNdyjACm9EgiZwm1BRjGaHiPTX2CSfg&mra=pe&mrcr=0&sll=49.005043,17.145969&sspn=24.626826,56.162109&ie=UTF8&ll=51.781436,21.181641&spn=23.253441,56.162109&z=4 |title=Athens International Airport to Oslo, Norway|publisher=Google Maps|date=1 January 1970|accessdate=20 April 2010}} Buses are allowed to have 18 hours effective driving time per 24 hours if two drivers.</ref> * Around 600 Mexican middle-school students, ranging from 12 to 16 years old, who had attended a competition in England for foreign students and scheduled to return home on 18 April were stranded for almost a week. Some started to return to Mexico on 21 April and by 24 April most of them were already home.
Stranded passengers were not necessarily given priority over new passengers for return flights. [[British Airways]] told passengers in India and China that any free seats were being sold on the open market, and advised them to buy new tickets and seek reimbursement on return.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/apr/22/british-airways-flights-refunds Stranded BA passengers sent to back of queue] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313000148/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/apr/22/british-airways-flights-refunds |date=13 March 2016 }} The Guardian, 22 April 2010</ref>
In addition to being stranded, some travelers also encountered issues with their visas after arriving at destinations unexpectedly: * At [[Brussels airport]], 200 travelers from [[Bangladesh]] were unable to leave the building without a [[visa (document)|visa]].<ref>"[http://abcnews.go.com/Travel/Green/volcanic-ash-strands-passengers-airport-cots-cramped-space/story?id=10396223&singlePage=true $5,500 Cab Ride? Volcanic Ash Strands Thousands at Airport, Even Grounds Jet Set]" ABC News, 16 April 2010</ref> * Passengers from [[Kolkata]] headed for London on an [[Air India]] flight were diverted to [[Frankfurt]], where they were unable to leave the airport to seek accommodation because they did not have visas for Germany.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1100417/jsp/foreign/story_12348927.jsp |title=Frankfurt horror for Indian passengers |first=Amit |last=Roy |publisher=[[The Telegraph (Kolkata)|''The Telegraph'' (Kolkata)]] |date=17 April 2010 |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420191042/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1100417/jsp/foreign/story_12348927.jsp| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> * A group of passengers from the United Kingdom were facing arrest in [[Delhi]] over a breach of immigration laws, because they left the airport without visas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hampshirechronicle.co.uk/news/8105580.Winchester_church_members_stranded_in_India/ |title=Winchester church members stranded in India |first=Andrew |last=Napier |publisher=[[Hampshire Chronicle]]|date=17 April 2010|accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421055313/http://www.hampshirechronicle.co.uk/news/8105580.Winchester_church_members_stranded_in_India/| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 17 April the [[UK Border Agency]] announced that it would make allowances for travellers who were unable to leave the UK and whose visas had expired, provided that evidence of travel reservations during the travel disruption was presented.<ref>{{cite web|author=UK Border Agency |url=http://ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/newsarticles/2010/april/07-expired-visas-ash |title=Notice for holders of expired visas whose travel plans have been disrupted by the volcanic ash |date=17 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717070729/http://ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/newsarticles/2010/april/07-expired-visas-ash |archivedate=17 July 2011 }}</ref> [[Belarus]], Serbia, [[Finland]], and [[Russia]] also eased visa formalities for affected passengers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://naviny.by/rubrics/english/2010/04/17/ic_news_259_329511/ |title=Belarus eases visa formalities for foreign passengers affected by European air chaos |publisher=Naviny.by |accessdate=20 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424070831/http://naviny.by/rubrics/english/2010/04/17/ic_news_259_329511/ |archivedate=24 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isria.com/pages/17_April_2010_60.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507154955/http://www.isria.com/pages/17_April_2010_60.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 May 2018 |title=Iceland’s volcanic eruption’s impacts on travel in Finland |publisher=[[ISRIA]] |accessdate=20 April 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=France |first=Agence |url=http://news.malaysia.msn.com/business/article.aspx?cp-documentid=4034907 |title=Belarus, Serbia waive transit formalities for stranded Europeans |publisher=MSN Malaysia |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422204154/http://news.malaysia.msn.com/business/article.aspx?cp-documentid=4034907 |archivedate=22 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irk.kp.ru/online/news/652342/ |title=Застрявшим в московских аэропортах иностранцам готовы продлить визы |publisher=KP.RU |date=23 March 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305235245/http://www.irk.kp.ru/online/news/652342/ |archivedate=5 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Alternative transport routes=== [[File:Volcano causes queue at Bergen Station.jpg|thumb|Queue at [[Bergen Station]] as travelers wait to purchase train tickets from the [[Norwegian State Railways]]]] Passengers destined for countries where airspace was closed had to switch to other modes of transport, possibly via airports still open in [[Portugal]], [[Morocco]], and [[Turkey]] to the east. Once inside Europe, many people tried to reach their final destination by train or road. People hired coaches, hire cars, and taxis while the train companies reported a large increase in passenger numbers.<ref>{{cite web|title=East Coast Railway provides extra train services as travellers switch from the skies |url=http://www.eastcoast.co.uk/about-us/Press-Release/2008/EAST-COAST-RAILWAY-PROVIDES-EXTRA-TRAIN-SERVICES-AS-TRAVELLERS-SWITCH-FROM-THE-SKIES/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418205735/http://www.eastcoast.co.uk/about-us/Press-Release/2008/EAST-COAST-RAILWAY-PROVIDES-EXTRA-TRAIN-SERVICES-AS-TRAVELLERS-SWITCH-FROM-THE-SKIES/ |archivedate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> [[Eurostar]] passenger trains were solidly booked, the [[Eurotunnel]] car-carrying trains which run through the [[Channel Tunnel]] were very busy, and additional services were scheduled. Travel conditions in France were compounded by an ongoing rail strike affecting long-distance trains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/319022,extra-volcanic-ash-rail-strike-disrupt-french-holiday-travel.html |title=EXTRA: Volcanic ash, rail strike disrupt French holiday travel |publisher=Earth Times|accessdate=17 April 2010}}</ref>
Most UK and Irish ferry routes were exceptionally busy and coach operator [[Bus Éireann]] arranged extra [[Eurolines]] services between Ireland and England via ferry. {{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}
The websites Twitter and Facebook, as well as other sites like Roadsharing, were used to arrange alternative travel plans involving boats and ships, trains, and other forms of transportation such as cars, as well as to try to find rooms for the night in the cities where they were stuck.<ref>{{cite web|title=Volcano-Stranded Travelers Turn to Social Media|url=http://gigaom.com/2010/04/17/volcano-stranded-travellers-turn-to-social-media/|publisher=The GigaOM Network|date=17 April 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420063447/http://gigaom.com/2010/04/17/volcano-stranded-travellers-turn-to-social-media/|archivedate=20 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As an alternative to face-to-face business meetings, [[videoconferencing]] was also used by the European Union, governments, and companies.<ref>[http://www.channelinsider.com/c/a/Cisco/Cisco-Iceland-Volcano-Boosts-Video-Conferencing-153040/ Cisco: Iceland Volcano Boosts Video Conferencing] Channelinsider, from Reuters, 20 April 2010</ref>
Many people who had to travel, particularly those stranded while away from their home countries, faced large costs for unanticipated travel and accommodation at a time of scarcity.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8630190.stm Volcano lifts travellers' prices but rip-offs seem rare] BBC News, 20 April 2010</ref> Some costs were covered by compensation from airlines and travel insurance,<ref>[http://www.travelbite.co.uk/news/flights-travel/which-holiday-volcano-ash-chaos-advice-$1372980.htm Holiday volcano ash chaos advice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100423154944/http://www.travelbite.co.uk/news/flights-travel/which-holiday-volcano-ash-chaos-advice-%241372980.htm |date=23 April 2010 }} Which?, 21 April 2010</ref> although there were many disputes over payments.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1267804/Iceland-volcano-Ryanair-WILL-pay-compensation-ash-victim-passengers.html Ryanair in dramatic U-turn: We WILL pay 'unfair' expenses to passengers stranded by volcanic ash] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120729155904/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1267804/Iceland-volcano-Ryanair-WILL-pay-compensation-ash-victim-passengers.html |date=29 July 2012 }} Mail Online, 23 April 2010</ref> Some people incurred large [[taxicab]] fares over long distances, such as [[John Cleese]], who took a taxi from [[Oslo]] to [[Brussels]].<ref>{{cite web|title=John Cleese takes taxi from Oslo to Brussels|url=http://www.swedishwire.com/business/3869-john-cleese-takes-taxi-from-oslo-to-brussels|publisher=The Swedish Wire|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419120529/http://www.swedishwire.com/business/3869-john-cleese-takes-taxi-from-oslo-to-brussels|archivedate=19 April 2010|df=dmy-all|access-date=20 April 2010}}</ref>
On 18 April [[Government of the United Kingdom|British ministers]] announced a plan for flights to land and take off in Spain, and to transport passengers by sea to the United Kingdom.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8628605.stm Volcano cloud Britons could return via 'Spanish hub'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422003826/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8628605.stm |date=22 April 2010 }} BBC News, 18 April 2010</ref> On 19 April the cabinet crisis response committee ([[Cabinet Office Briefing Room|COBRA]]) decided that [[Royal Navy]] ships should be utilised to [[repatriation|repatriate]] stranded British travellers, in [[Operation Cunningham]]. [[HMS Ark Royal (R07)|HMS ''Ark Royal'']], [[HMS Ocean (L12)|HMS ''Ocean'']], and [[HMS Albion (L14)|HMS ''Albion'']] were deployed, but only Albion was directly involved in repatriation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8628878.stm |title=Royal Navy ships to return Britons stranded by volcano |date=19 April 2010 |publisher=BBC News|accessdate=19 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421170919/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8628878.stm| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
After the disruption in [[transatlantic flight]], the [[Cunard Line]] said its volume of calls inquiring about booking passage on its [[ocean liner]] [[RMS Queen Mary 2|RMS ''Queen Mary 2'']] by stranded air passengers wishing to [[transatlantic crossing|cross by ship]] had tripled since the weekend of 16 April.<ref>{{cite news |title=City Room: Airliners' Loss Is Ocean Liners' Gain |author=James Barron |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/21/airliners-loss-is-ocean-liners-gain/ |newspaper=The New York Times |date=21 April 2010 |accessdate=23 December 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110423231845/http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/21/airliners-loss-is-ocean-liners-gain/ |archivedate=23 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Criticism of airspace closure== There was much criticism by airlines, which suffered large financial losses, of the airspace closures as unnecessary; however, the [[Presidency of the Council of the European Union|EU transport presidency]] disagreed, saying that "This situation is causing them important losses, but safety is paramount".<ref>[http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/iceland-volcano.478 EU disagrees with airlines' criticism over airspace closure] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422113527/http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/iceland-volcano.478 |date=22 April 2010 }} EU Business, 19 April 2010</ref>
==Military flying== Some military aircraft which flew during the period of closure suffered engine damage, although no crashes were reported.
On 15 April, five [[Finnish Air Force]] [[F-18]] fighter jets on exercise flew into the ash cloud in northern Finland. Volcanic dust was found on the engines of three of the aircraft and a further inspection revealed extensive damage by molten glass deposits inside the combustion chamber of one of the engines. The engines were sent for disassembly and overhaul. As a result, all unnecessary military flights were cancelled except for identification flights to enforce sovereign airspace. Meanwhile, a [[BAE Hawk]] trainer with special equipment to sample the volcanic dust was being flown from the 41st squadron in [[Kauhava]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Hoyle |first=Craig |accessdate=17 April 2010 |title=PICTURES: Finnish F-18 engine check reveals effects of volcanic dust |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/04/16/340727/pictures-finnish-f-18-engine-check-reveals-effects-of-volcanic.html|work=Flight International |date=16 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418033522/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/04/16/340727/pictures-finnish-f-18-engine-check-reveals-effects-of-volcanic.html| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/alueet/keski-suomi/2010/04/tuhka_vaurioitti_ilmavoimien_horneteja_1610459.html |title=Tuhka vaurioitti ilmavoimien Hornet-hävittäjiä | Keski-Suomi |publisher=yle.fi |accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100419132344/http://yle.fi/alueet/keski-suomi/2010/04/tuhka_vaurioitti_ilmavoimien_horneteja_1610459.html| archivedate= 19 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Even short test flights with an F-18 revealed engine damage sufficient to destroy engines.<ref name=GlassBuild>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE63I18820100419 |title=UPDATE 3-Glass build-up found in NATO F-16 engine-US official Keski-Suomi |publisher=Reuters |date=19 April 2010 |accessdate=20 April 2010 |first=David |last=Brunnstrom |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100423081601/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE63I18820100419 |archivedate=23 April 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
On 19 April, [[NATO]] reported finding molten glass in the engines of at least one [[F-16]], the result of flying through the ash cloud, leading to the scaling-down of U.S. military exercises.<ref name=GlassBuild/> [[Royal Air Force]] flights to [[Selly Oak Hospital]] in Birmingham were grounded, and the [[United Kingdom Ministry of Defence]] considered flying [[British Forces casualties in Afghanistan since 2001|British casualties of the Afghan War]] to [[International Security Assistance Force|coalition countries]].<ref name=Guardian18Apr2010Impact>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/apr/18/iceland-volcano-ash-economy-airlines |title=Iceland volcano: the impact of the ash cloud on Britain |work=The Guardian |date=18 April 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2010 | first=James | last=Meikle | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421045508/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/apr/18/iceland-volcano-ash-economy-airlines| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 23 April it was announced that British [[Royal Air Force]] training flights had been suspended following volcanic ash damage to the engines of [[Eurofighter Typhoon]] aircraft.<ref name="grounded">{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/raf-grounds-fighter-jets-after-volcanic-dust-is-found-in-engines-1951953.html |title= RAF grounds fighter jets after volcanic dust is found in engines |work=The Independent |date=23 April 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2010 | first=Martin | last= Hickman | location=London | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100425053858/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/raf-grounds-fighter-jets-after-volcanic-dust-is-found-in-engines-1951953.html| archivedate= 25 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
== Impacts of the disruption == {{Main|Effects of the April 2010 Eyjafjallajökull eruption}} The disruption accelerated the integration of the national air traffic control systems into the [[Single European Sky]] and the immediate creation of a crisis coordination group to handle future transportation disruptions.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/05/world/europe/05ash.html European Union Agrees to Accelerate Joint Control of Skies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109164701/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/05/world/europe/05ash.html |date=9 November 2016 }} New York Times, 5 May 2010</ref>
The ash indirectly affected [[Effects of the April 2010 Eyjafjallajökull eruption#Cultural impacts|many scheduled cultural and sporting events]] because key participants were unable to attend, including the funeral of Polish president [[Lech Kaczyński]] in [[Kraków]] on 18 April 2010. The funeral was to have been attended by 69 presidents, prime ministers, and other heads of states. Almost half of these, including [[Barack Obama]], [[Angela Merkel]], [[José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero]], [[Stephen Harper]], and [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], were unable to travel to Poland because of the disrupted air traffic.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.pl/artykuly/sekcje/polska/kto-nie-przyjedzie-na-pogrzeb-glowy-panstw-odwoluja-wizyty,56858,1 |title=Pył wulkaniczny sprawia, że głowy państw odwołują wizyty – Wiadomości |publisher=Newsweek.pl |accessdate=18 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608070910/http://www.newsweek.pl/artykuly/sekcje/polska/kto-nie-przyjedzie-na-pogrzeb-glowy-panstw-odwoluja-wizyty,56858,1# |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gkxIpKRIMod1M5iJlnofIi4YQl4A|title=Ash stops Charles, Miliband attending Kaczynski funeral|agency=AFP|date=17 April 2010|accessdate=18 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420074658/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gkxIpKRIMod1M5iJlnofIi4YQl4A| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
There was also a wider impact on the economies of several countries. However, there were some environmental advantages arising from a saving of around 1.3 to 2.8 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions.
==Ash cloud maps== The following maps, with the volcano in red, depict the progress of the ash cloud during the period of disruption.
<gallery class="center"> File:Eyjafjallajökull volcanic ash 14 April 2010.png|Depiction of the estimated ash cloud at 18:00 UTC on 14 April 2010. {{chembox | Verifiedfields = changed | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 455377376 | Name = Barium titanate | ImageFile = BaTiO3ceramics.JPG | ImageCaption=Polycrystalline BaTiO<sub>3</sub> in plastic | ImageName = Barium titanate ceramics in plastic package | OtherNames = |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | InChI = 1/2Ba.4O.Ti/q2*+2;4*-1;/r2Ba.O4Ti/c;;1-5(2,3)4/q2*+2;-4 | SMILES = [Ba+2].[Ba+2].[O-][Ti]([O-])([O-])[O-] | InChIKey = JRPBQTZRNDNNOP-NXYSCRTKAD | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/2Ba.4O.Ti/q2*+2;4*-1; | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = JRPBQTZRNDNNOP-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | CASNo = 12047-27-7 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID =10605734 | PubChem = 6101006 | RTECS = XR1437333 }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = BaTiO<sub>3</sub> | MolarMass = 233.192 g | Appearance = white crystals | Odor = odorless | BandGap = 3.2 eV (300 K, single crystal)<ref name=bandgap>{{cite journal|doi=10.1143/JJAP.44.2081|title=Optical Band Gap of Barium Titanate Nanoparticles Prepared by RF-plasma Chemical Vapor Deposition|journal=Jpn. J. Appl. Phys. |volume=44 |issue=4A|year=2005|pages=2081–2082|last1=Suzuki |first1=Keigo |last2=Kijima |first2=Kazunori |bibcode=2005JaJAP..44.2081S}}</ref> | Density = 6.02 g/cm<sup>3</sup>, solid | Solubility = insoluble | SolubleOther = slightly soluble in dilute mineral acids; dissolves in concentrated [[hydrofluoric acid]] | MeltingPtC = 1625 | MeltingPt_notes = | BoilingPt = | RefractIndex=n<sub>o</sub>2.412; n<sub>e</sub>=2.360<ref name="Tong2013">{{cite book|last=Tong |first=Xingcun Colin |title=Advanced Materials for Integrated Optical Waveguides|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V1K6BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA357|date= 2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-3-319-01550-7|page=357}}</ref> }} |Section3={{Chembox Structure | CrystalStruct = [[Tetragonal]], [[Pearson symbol|tP5]] | SpaceGroup = P4mm, No. 99 }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | ExternalSDS = | EUClass = | RPhrases = {{R20/22}} | SPhrases = {{S28}}A, {{S37}}, and {{S45}} }} }}
'''Barium titanate''' is an [[inorganic compound]] with [[chemical formula]] BaTiO<sub>3</sub>. Barium titanate appears white as a powder and is transparent when prepared as large crystals. It is a [[ferroelectric]] [[ceramic]] material that exhibits the [[photorefractive effect]] and [[piezoelectric]] properties. It is used in [[capacitor]]s, [[electromechanical]] [[transducer]]s and [[nonlinear optic]]s.
==Structure== {{Main|Perovskite (structure)}} [[File:Perovskite.jpg|thumb|left|Structure of cubic BaTiO<sub>3</sub>. The red spheres are oxide centres, blue are Ti<sup>4+</sup> cations, and the green spheres are Ba<sup>2+</sup>.]] The solid exists in one of five polymorphs depending on temperature. From high to low temperature, these crystal symmetries of the five polymorphs are [[Hexagonal lattice system|hexagonal]], [[Cubic crystal system|cubic]], [[Tetragonal crystal system|tetragonal]], [[Orthorhombic crystal system|orthorhombic]], and [[Trigonal crystal system|rhombohedral]] [[crystal structure]]. All of these phases exhibit the [[ferroelectric effect]] apart from the cubic phase. The high temperature cubic phase is easiest to describe, as it consists of regular corner-sharing octahedral TiO<sub>6</sub> units that define a cube with O vertices and Ti-O-Ti edges. In the cubic phase, Ba<sup>2+</sup> is located at the center of the cube, with a nominal [[coordination number]] of 12. Lower symmetry phases are stabilized at lower temperatures and involve movement of the Ba<sup>2+</sup> to off-center position. The remarkable properties of this material arise from the cooperative behavior of the Ba<sup>2+</sup> ions.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}}
==Production and handling properties== Barium titanate can be synthesized by the relatively simple [[Hydrothermal synthesis|sol–hydrothermal]] method.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Selvaraj |first1=M. |last2=Venkatachalapathy |first2=V. |last3=Mayandi |first3=J. |last4=Karazhanov |first4=S. |last5=Pearce |first5=J. M. |title=Preparation of meta-stable phases of barium titanate by Sol-hydrothermal method |journal=AIP Advances |volume=5 |issue=11 |pages=117119 |url=https://www.academia.edu/18077811 |doi=10.1063/1.4935645|year=2015 |bibcode=2015AIPA....5k7119S }}</ref> Barium titanate can also be manufactured by heating [[barium carbonate]] and [[titanium dioxide]]. The reaction proceeds via [[sintering#Liquid phase sintering|liquid phase sintering]]. Single crystals can be grown at around 1100 °C from molten [[potassium fluoride]].<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Galasso | first1 = Francis S. | year = 1973 | title = Barium Titanate, BaTiO<sub>3</sub>| journal = Inorganic Syntheses | volume = 14 | issue = | pages = 142–143 | doi = 10.1002/9780470132456.ch28 | isbn = 9780470132456 }}</ref> Other materials are often added as [[doping (semiconductors)|dopants]], e.g., Sr to giveform solid solutions with [[strontium titanate]]. It reacts with [[nitrogen trichloride]] and produces a greenish or gray mixture; the [[ferroelectric]] properties of the mixture are still present in this form.
Much effort has been spent studying the relationship between particle morphology and its properties. Fully dense nanocrystalline barium titanate has 40% higher [[permittivity]] than the same material prepared in classic ways.<ref>{{cite journal| doi=10.1021/jp7112818| title=Effect of Microwave Frequency on Hydrothermal Synthesis of Nanocrystalline Tetragonal Barium Titanate| year=2008 |last=Nyutu |first=Edward K.| journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry C| volume=112| pages=9659| last2=Chen| first2=Chun-Hu| last3=Dutta| first3=Prabir K.| last4=Suib| first4=Steven L.| issue=26| citeseerx=10.1.1.660.3769}}</ref> The addition of inclusions of barium titanate to [[tin]] has been shown to produce a bulk material with a higher viscoelastic [[stiffness]] than that of diamonds. Barium titanate goes through two phase transitions that change the crystal shape and volume. This phase change leads to composites where the barium titanates have a negative bulk modulus ([[Young's modulus]]), meaning that when a force acts on the inclusions, there is displacement in the opposite direction, further stiffening the composite.<ref>{{cite journal| doi = 10.1126/science.1135837| year=2007 |last1=Jaglinski |first1=T. |last2=Kochmann |first2=D. |last3=Stone |first3=D. |last4=Lakes |first4=R. S. | title = Composite materials with viscoelastic stiffness greater than diamond| volume = 315| issue = 5812| pages = 620–2| pmid = 17272714| journal = Science|bibcode=2007Sci...315..620J| citeseerx=10.1.1.1025.8289 }}</ref>
Like many [[oxide]]s, barium titanate is insoluble in water but attacked by [[sulfuric acid]]. Its bulk room-temperature [[bandgap]] is 3.2 eV, but this increases to ~3.5 eV when the particle size is reduced from about 15 to 7 nm.<ref name=bandgap/>
==Uses== [[File:BaTiO3 ferro domains.jpg|thumb|[[Scanning transmission electron microscopy]] of the ferroelastic domains that form in BaTiO<sub>3</sub> on cooling through the [[Curie temperature]]. The vertex point, where domain bundles meet, moves from the center in isometric crystals (top) to off-center in oblongs (bottom).<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1088/1468-6996/16/3/036001| pmid = 27877812| title = Some current problems in perovskite nano-ferroelectrics and multiferroics: Kinetically-limited systems of finite lateral size| journal = Science and Technology of Advanced Materials| volume = 16| issue = 3| pages = 036001| year = 2015| last1 = Scott | first1 = J. F. | last2 = Schilling | first2 = A. | last3 = Rowley | first3 = S. E. | last4 = Gregg | first4 = J. M. |pmc=5099849| bibcode = 2015STAdM..16c6001S}}</ref>]] Barium titanate is a [[dielectric]] ceramic used in [[capacitor]]s, with dielectric constant values as high as 7,000. Over a narrow temperature range, values as high as 15,000 are possible; most common ceramic and polymer materials are less than 10, while others, such as titanium dioxide (TiO2), have values between 20 and 70.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Design solutions for DC bias in multilayer ceramic capacitors|last = Waugh|first = Mark D|date = 2010|journal = Electronic Engineering Times|url=http://www.compel.ru/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/Mark-D.-Waugh.pdf}}</ref>
It is a [[piezoelectric]] material used in [[microphone]]s and other [[transducer]]s. The spontaneous polarization of barium titanate single crystals at room temperature range between 0.15 C/m<sup>2</sup> in earlier studies,<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1103/RevModPhys.22.221| volume = 22| issue = 3| pages = 221–237| last = von Hippel| first = A.| title = Ferroelectricity, Domain Structure, and Phase Transitions of Barium Titanate| journal = Reviews of Modern Physics| date = 1950-07-01| bibcode=1950RvMP...22..221V}}</ref> and 0.26 C/m<sup>2</sup> in more recent publications,<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.mseb.2008.11.046| issn = 0921-5107| volume = 161| issue = 1–3| pages = 50–54| last1 = Shieh| first1 = J.| last2 = Yeh| first2 = J. H.| last3 = Shu| first3 = Y. C.| last4 = Yen| first4 = J. H.| title = Hysteresis behaviors of barium titanate single crystals based on the operation of multiple 90° switching systems| journal = Materials Science and Engineering: B| series = Proceedings of the joint meeting of the 2nd International Conference on the Science and Technology for Advanced Ceramics (STAC-II) and the 1st International Conference on the Science and Technology of Solid Surfaces and Interfaces (STSI-I)| accessdate = 2015-11-05| date = 2009-04-15| url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0921510708006168}}</ref> and its [[Curie temperature]] is between 120 and 130 °C. The differences are related to the growth technique, with earlier [[flux method|flux grown]] crystals being less pure than current crystals grown with the [[Czochralski process]],<ref>{{Cite journal| volume = base documentaire : TIB271DUO.| issue = ref. article : e1870| last = Godefroy| first = Geneviève| title = Ferroélectricité| journal = Techniques de l'Ingénieur Matériaux Pour l'Électronique et Dispositifs Associés| date = 1996| language = fr}}</ref> which therefore have a larger spontaneous polarization and a higher Curie temperature.
As a [[piezoelectric]] material, it has been largely replaced by [[lead zirconate titanate]], also known as PZT. Polycrystalline barium titanate has a positive [[temperature coefficient]] of resistance, making it a useful material for [[thermistor]]s and self-regulating electric heating systems.
Barium titanate crystals find use in [[nonlinear optics]]. The material has high beam-coupling gain, and can be operated at visible and near-infrared wavelengths. It has the highest reflectivity of the materials used for self-pumped [[optical phase conjugation|phase conjugation]] (SPPC) applications. It can be used for continuous-wave [[four-wave mixing]] with milliwatt-range optical power. For photorefractive applications, barium titanate can be doped by various other elements, e.g. [[iron]].<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.redoptronics.com/Fe-LiNbO3-crystal.html| title = Fe:LiNbO<sub>3</sub> Crystal|work=redoptronics.com}}</ref>
[[Thin film]]s of barium titanate display [[Electro-optic modulator|electrooptic modulation]] to frequencies over 40 GHz.<ref>{{cite journal| doi = 10.1364/OPEX.12.005962| title = Electrooptic modulation up to 40 GHz in a barium titanate thin film waveguide modulator| year = 2004 |last1=Tang |first1=Pingsheng |journal=Optics Express |volume=12 |issue=24 |pages=5962–7 |pmid=19488237 |last2=Towner |first2=D. |last3=Hamano |first3=T. |last4=Meier|first4=A. |last5=Wessels |first5=B.|bibcode=2004OExpr..12.5962T }}</ref>
The pyroelectric and ferroelectric properties of barium titanate are used in some types of uncooled sensors for [[thermal camera]]s.
High purity barium titanate powder is reported to be a key component of new barium titanate capacitor energy storage systems for use in electric vehicles.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://gtresearchnews.gatech.edu/newsrelease/barium-titanate.htm| accessdate=2009-06-06| title = Nanoparticle Compatibility: New Nanocomposite Processing Technique Creates More Powerful Capacitors|work=gatech.edu|date=April 26, 2007}}</ref>
Due to their elevated [[biocompatibility]], barium titanate [[nanoparticle]]s (BTNPs) have been recently employed as nanocarriers for [[drug delivery]].<ref>{{Cite journal| doi =10.1088/0957-4484/27/23/232001| pmid = 27145888 | issn = 09574484 | volume =27| issue = 23| pages =232001| last1 =Genchi | first1 = G.G.| last2 =Marino| first2 = A.| last3 =Rocca| first3 =A. | last4 =Mattoli | first4 = V. | last5= Ciofani| first5 = G.| title = Barium titanate nanoparticles: Promising multitasking vectors in nanomedicine | journal = Nanotechnology| date =5 May 2016| bibcode =2016Nanot..27w2001G}}</ref>
Magnetoelectric effect of giant strengths have been reported in thin films grown on barium titanate substrates.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eerenstein|first=W.|last2=Mathur|first2=N. D.|last3=Scott|first3=J. F.|date=August 2006|title=Multiferroic and magnetoelectric materials|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature05023|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=442|issue=7104|pages=759–765|doi=10.1038/nature05023|pmid=16915279|issn=1476-4687|bibcode=2006Natur.442..759E}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rafique|first=Mohsin|date=May 2017|title=Giant room temperature magnetoelectric response in strain controlled nanocomposites|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=110|issue=20|pages=202902|doi=10.1063/1.4983357}}</ref>
==Natural occurrence== Barioperovskite is a very rare natural analogue of BaTiO<sub>3</sub>, found as microinclusions in [[benitoite]].<ref>{{cite journal| year = 2008|last1=Ma |first1=Chi |last2=Rossman |first2=George R. |title=Barioperovskite, BaTiO<sub>3</sub>, a new mineral from the Benitoite Mine, California| volume = 93|issue=1 | pages = 154–157| journal = American Mineralogist| doi=10.2138/am.2008.2636|bibcode=2008AmMin..93..154M}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Strontium titanate]] *[[Lead zirconate titanate]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Barium titanate}} *[http://gtresearchnews.gatech.edu/newsrelease/barium-titanate.htm Nanoparticle Compatibility: New Nanocomposite Processing Technique Creates More Powerful Capacitors] *[http://blog.wired.com/gadgets/2007/09/instant-charge-.html EEStor's "instant-charge" capacitor batteries]

revision.text:
'''Computational thermodynamics''' is the use of computers to simulate [[thermodynamic]] problems specific to [[materials science]], particularly used in the construction of phase diagrams.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Computational_Thermodynamics_of_Material.html?id=0J5ODAAAQBAJ|title=Computational Thermodynamics of Materials|last=Liu|first=Zi-Kui|last2=Wang|first2=Yi|date=2016-06-30|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521198967|language=en}}</ref> Several open and commercial programs exist to perform these operations. The concept of the technique is minimization of [[Gibbs free energy]] of the system; the success of this method is due not only to properly measuring thermodynamic properties, such as those in the [[list of thermodynamic properties]], but also due to the extrapolation of the properties of metastable [[Allotropy|allotropes]] of the [[chemical element]]s.
==History== The computational modeling of metal-based phase diagrams, which dates back to the beginning of the previous century mainly by [[Johannes van Laar]] and to the modeling of [[regular solution]]s, has evolved in more recent years to the [[CALPHAD]] (CALculation of PHAse Diagrams).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0ZDuCAAAQBAJ&dq=saxena+Thermodynamic+Data+on+Oxides+and+Silicates,+Springer,+New+York+(1993)|title=Thermodynamic Data, Models, and Phase Diagrams in Multicomponent Oxide Systems: An Assessment for Materials and Planetary Scientists Based on Calorimetric, Volumetric and Phase Equilibrium Data|last=Fabrichnaya|first=Olga|last2=Saxena|first2=Surendra K.|last3=Richet|first3=Pascal|last4=Westrum|first4=Edgar F.|date=2013-03-14|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9783662105047|language=en}}</ref> This has been pioneered by American [[metallurgist]] Larry Kaufman since the 1970s.<ref>L Kaufman and H Bernstein, Computer Calculation of Phase Diagrams, Academic Press N Y (1970) {{ISBN|0-12-402050-X}}{{page needed|date=April 2017}}</ref><ref>N Saunders and P Miodownik, Calphad, Pergamon Materials Series, Vol 1 Ed. R W Cahn (1998) {{ISBN|0-08-042129-6}}{{page needed|date=April 2017}}</ref><ref>H L Lukas, S G Fries and B Sundman, Computational Thermodynamics, the Calphad Method, Cambridge University Press (2007) {{ISBN|0-521-86811-4}}{{page needed|date=April 2017}}</ref>
==Current state== Computational thermodynamics may be considered a part of [[materials informatics]] and is a cornerstone of the concepts behind the [[Materials Genome|materials genome]] project. While crystallographic databases are used mainly as a reference source, thermodynamic databases represent one of the earliest examples of informatics, as these databases were integrated into [[Thermochemistry|thermochemical computations]] to map phase stability in binary and ternary [[alloy]]s.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Thermodynamic Data on Oxides and Silicates : an Assessed Data Set Based on Thermochemistry and High Pressure Phase Equilibrium|last=K.|first=Saxena, Surendra|date=1993|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|others=Chatterjee, Nilanjan., Fei, Yingwei., Shen, Guoyin.|isbn=9783642783326|location=Berlin, Heidelberg|oclc=840299125}}</ref> Many concepts and software used in computational thermodynamics are credited to the SGTE Group, a [[consortium]] devoted to the development of thermodynamic databases; the open elements database is freely available<ref>http://www.crct.polymtl.ca/sgte/unary50.tdb{{full citation needed|date=April 2017}}</ref> based on the paper by Dinsdale.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0364-5916(91)90030-N |title=SGTE data for pure elements |journal=Calphad |volume=15 |issue=4 |pages=317–425 |year=1991 |last1=Dinsdale |first1=A.T. }}</ref> This so-called "unary" system proves to be a common basis for the development of binary and multiple systems and is used by both commercial and open software in this field.
However, as stated in recent{{When|date=December 2017}} CALPHAD papers and meetings, such a Dinsdale/SGTE database will likely need to be corrected over time despite the utility in keeping a common base. In this case, most published assessments will likely have to be revised, similarly to rebuilding a house due to a severely broken foundation. This concept has also been depicted as an "inverted pyramid."<ref>http://web.micress.de/ICMEg1/presentations_pdfs/Hallstedt.pdf{{full citation needed|date=April 2017}}</ref> Merely extending the current approach (limited to temperatures above room temperature) is a complex task.<ref>http://thermocalc.micress.de/proceedings/proceedings2015/tc2015_tumminello_public.pdf{{full citation needed|date=April 2017}}</ref> PyCalpahd, a [[Python (programming language)#Libraries|Python library]], was designed to facilitate simple computational thermodynamics calculation using [[Open-source software|open source code]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.5334/jors.140 |title=Pycalphad: CALPHAD-based Computational Thermodynamics in Python |journal=Journal of Open Research Software |volume=5 |year=2017 |last1=Otis |first1=Richard |last2=Liu |first2=Zi-Kui }}</ref> In complex systems, computational methods such as CALPHAD are employed to model thermodynamic properties for each phase and simulate multicomponent phase behavior.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Computational thermodynamics : the CALPHAD method|last=L.|first=Lukas, H.|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|others=Fries, Suzana G., Sundman, Bo.|isbn=978-0521868112|location=Cambridge|oclc=663969016}}</ref> The application of CALPHAD to high pressures in some important applications, which are not restricted to one side of materials science like the [[Fe-C system]],<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.epsl.2014.09.044 |title=Experimental study and thermodynamic calculations of phase relations in the Fe–C system at high pressure |journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters |volume=408 |pages=155–62 |year=2014 |last1=Fei |first1=Yingwei |last2=Brosh |first2=Eli |bibcode=2014E&PSL.408..155F }}</ref> confirms experimental results by using computational thermodynamic calculations of phase relations in the Fe–C system at high pressures. Other scientists even considered [[viscosity]] and other physical parameters, which are beyond the domain of thermodynamics.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.calphad.2015.04.001 |title=Modeling of the viscosity in the AL–Cu–Mg–Si system: Database construction |journal=Calphad |volume=49 |pages=79–86 |year=2015 |last1=Zhang |first1=Fan |last2=Du |first2=Yong |last3=Liu |first3=Shuhong |last4=Jie |first4=Wanqi }}</ref>
==Future developments== There is still a gap between ab initio methods<ref>P. Turchi AB INITIO AND CALPHAD THERMODYNAMICS OF MATERIALS https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/306920.pdf</ref> and operative computational thermodynamics databases. In the past, a simplified approach introduced by the early works of Larry Kaufman, based on [[Miedema's Model]], was employed to check the correctness of even the simplest [[binary number|binary]] systems. However, relating the two communities to [[Solid State Physics]] and [[Materials Science]] remains a challenge,<ref>J. A. Alonso and N. H. March Electrons in Metals and Alloys http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/book/9780120536207{{page needed|date=April 2017}}</ref> as it has been for many years.<ref>https://www.elsevier.com/books/proceedings-of-the-international-symposium-on-thermodynamics-of-alloys/miedema/978-1-4832-2782-5{{full citation needed|date=April 2017}}{{page needed|date=April 2017}}</ref> Promising results from ab initio [[quantum mechanics]] molecular simulation packages like VASP - [[Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package]] are readily integrated in thermodynamic databases with approaches like Zentool.<ref>http://zengen.cnrs.fr/manual.pdf{{full citation needed|date=April 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Phase diagram]] * [[Gibbs energy]] * [[Enthalpy of mixing]] * [[Miedema's Model]] * [[Materials Genome]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0036-9748(70)90207-3 |title=Computer calculations of multicomponent phase diagrams |journal=Scripta Metallurgica |volume=4 |issue=9 |pages=685–91 |year=1970 |last1=Gaye |first1=Henri |last2=Lupis |first2=C.H.P }} * [http://www.calphad.org Official CALPHAD website] *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.calphad.2010.07.005 |title=Gibbs: Phase equilibria and symbolic computation of thermodynamic properties |journal=Calphad |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages=393–404 |year=2010 |last1=Cool |first1=Thomas |last2=Bartol |first2=Alexander |last3=Kasenga |first3=Matthew |last4=Modi |first4=Kunal |last5=García |first5=R. Edwin }} * [https://nanohub.org/resources/gibbs Python-based libraries for the calculation of phase diagrams and thermodynamic properties] * [http://cpddb.nims.go.jp/index_en.html Computational Phase Diagram Database (CPDDB), binary databases, free access with a registration ] * [http://www.opencalphad.com/ Open Calphad ] * [http://www.thermocalc.com/academia/students/ Thermocalc for Students ] * [http://www.computherm.com/ Pandat (free up to three components) ] * [http://matcalc.tuwien.ac.at/ Matcalc (free up to three components, open databases available)] * [http://www.metallurgy.nist.gov/phase/papers/jom/thermo_model.html Thermodynamic Modeling of Multicomponent Phase Equilibria ] * [http://www.metallurgy.nist.gov/phase/ NIST] * [http://www.nonmet.mat.ethz.ch/research/Modelling/Thermodynamic_Modelling Thermodynamic Modeling using the Calphad Method at [[ETH Zurich]] ] * [http://melts.ofm-research.org/history.html MELTS Software for thermodynamic modeling of phase equilibria in magmatic systems ] * [http://www.crct.polymtl.ca/sgte/ SGTE Scientific Group Thermodata Europe ] * [http://www.eoht.info/page/Larry+Kaufman Larry Kaufman at Hmolpedia] * {{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.calphad.2011.08.008 |title=Working with Larry Kaufman: Some thoughts on his 80th birthday |journal=Calphad |volume=36 |pages=iii–iv |nopp=yes |year=2012 |last1=Miodownik |first1=Peter }} * {{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.scriptamat.2012.12.003 |title=CALPHAD, first and second generation – Birth of the materials genome |journal=Scripta Materialia |volume=70 |pages=3–6 |year=2014 |last1=Kaufman |first1=Larry |last2=Ågren |first2=John }}
==University Courses on Computational Thermodynamics== *[https://www.kth.se/student/kurser/kurs/MH1028?l=en Computational Thermodynamics for Materials Design KTH, Sweden ] *[https://bulletins.psu.edu/university-course-descriptions/graduate/matse/?1=en MatSE580: Computational Thermodynamics of Materials, Pennsylvania State University, USA] *[https://is.muni.cz/predmety/predmet.pl?kod=C5305&fakulta=1431&lang=en&obdobi=6666 Computational Thermodynamics University of Brno, Czech Republic]
[[Category:Computational physics]] [[Category:Materials science]]

revision.text:
'''Coral calcium''' is a [[salt (chemistry)|salt]] of [[calcium]] derived from [[fossil]]ized [[coral reef]]s (primarily from limestone and coastal deposits). It has been promoted as an alternative, but unsubstantiated, treatment or cure for a number of health conditions.
== Health claims == Coral calcium has been promoted as an [[alternative medicine|alternative]] treatment or cure for a number of health conditions, often as part of an [[alkaline diet]], by Robert Barefoot and others; Barefoot coauthored a book called ''The Calcium Factor,'' and marketed coral calcium supplements with infomercials.<ref name="jaroff">{{cite news|last1=Jaroff|first1=Leon|title=Coral Calcium: A Barefoot Scam|url=http://www.time.com/time/columnist/jaroff/article/0,9565,433084,00.html|work=Time|date=14 March 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030605152023/http://www.time.com/time/columnist/jaroff/article/0,9565,433084,00.html|archivedate=5 June 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Barrett|first1=Stephen|title=A Critical Look at Robert Barefoot and Coral Calcium|url=https://www.quackwatch.org/01QuackeryRelatedTopics/DSH/coral.html|publisher=Quakcwatch|date=13 September 2012}}</ref> According to a ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine article about Barefoot by Leon Jaroff, "The monthly cost of the recommended dose of Barefoot's calcium tablets is some 15 times greater than that of the ordinary drug store variety." Jaroff called Barefoot's marketing of coral calcium "one of the more successful scams of our age" and "sheer nonsense," and labeled him a "huckster".<ref name="jaroff"/>
There is no medical evidence to support these [[health claims]], and coral calcium has been identified by the United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] as a "Fake Cancer 'Cure' Consumers Should Avoid".<ref name=FDA2>{{cite web|title=187 Fake Cancer "Cures" Consumers Should Avoid|url=http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/EnforcementActivitiesbyFDA/ucm171057.htm|publisher=FDA|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115170816/http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/EnforcementActivitiesbyFDA/ucm171057.htm|archivedate=15 November 2017|date=25 April 2017}}</ref> The [[Federal Trade Commission]] prosecuted several individuals, including Barefoot, for making unsupported health claims about coral calcium,<ref name=FTC>{{cite web | url = http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2003/06/trudeau.shtm | publisher = [[Federal Trade Commission]] | date = 2003-06-10 | accessdate = 2009-01-15 | title = FTC Charges Marketers of Coral Calcium Supreme Dietary Supplement and a Pain-Relief Product With Making False and Unsubstantiated Claims}}</ref> and the [[National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine]] has issued a consumer advisory regarding false and misleading marketing claims associated with coral calcium supplements.<ref name=NCCAM>{{cite web|url=http://nccih.nih.gov/news/alerts/coral/coral.htm|title=Consumer Advisory: Coral Calcium|publisher=[[National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health]]|date=November 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041018060615/http://nccam.nih.gov/health/alerts/coral/coral.htm|archivedate=18 October 2004}}</ref>
==Health and environmental concerns== Living coral reefs are endangered and cannot be harvested without significant damage to the ecosystem, and because of this, coral calcium is harvested by grinding up above-ground [[limestone]] deposits that were once part of a coral reef. Calcium from coral sources needs to be refined to remove pollutants of the source environment. It is marketed as a [[dietary supplement]], but its benefits over other calcium supplements are unproven and biologically unlikely,<ref name=NCCAM/> and several marketers have been found guilty of fraud and were ordered to pay $20.4 million and to refrain from making unsubstantiated claims in the future.<ref name=FTC/> Additionally, coral near [[Okinawa]] has absorbed relatively high amounts of lead and mercury, leading to concern that these unregulated supplements may be contaminated.<ref name=JADA>{{cite journal |author=Blumberg S |title=Is coral calcium a safe and effective supplement? |journal=J Am Diet Assoc |volume=104 |issue=9 |pages=1335–6 |date=September 2004 |pmid=15354144 |doi=10.1016/j.jada.2004.07.022 |url=}}</ref> Further, [[coral]] takes millennia to grow, leading to environmental concerns if harvesting of live coral becomes widespread.<ref name=JADA/>
==See also== *Bob Barefoot product websites: *[https://www.robertbarefootcoralcalcium.com/ RobertBarefootCoralCalcium.com] *[http://www.thecoralcalciumstore.com/ TheCoralCalciumStore.com/] *[http://www.coralcalciumsupreme.com/ CoralCalciumSupreme.com/] *[[List of ineffective cancer treatments]]
