revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox news event |title = Torre Ejecutiva Pemex explosion |image = [[File:TORRE DE PEMEX.jpg|300px]] |image_name = |image_size = |caption = Headquarters for Pemex in [[Mexico City]] |date = {{Start date|2013|01|31|df=y}} |time = 15:45 ([[Central Time Zone|CST]]) |place = [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]] |coordinates = {{coord|19|26|19|N|99|10|30|W|region:MX_type:event|display=inline,title}} |also known as = |cause = [[Gas leak]], [[Gas explosion]] |first reporter = |filmed by = |participants = |outcome = |reported death(s) =37 |reported injuries =126 |reported missing = |reported property damage = |burial = |inquiries = |inquest = |coroner = |suspects = |charges = |verdict = |convictions = |publication bans = |litigation = |awards = |url = |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |notes = }} <!-- Per MOS:BOLDTITLE and WP:SBE, neither the article's title nor related text appears in bold. -->On 31 January 2013 in [[Mexico City]], an explosion caused by a gas leak occurred beneath Building B-2 at the [[Torre Ejecutiva Pemex]] (Pemex Executive Tower), a skyscraper complex that is the headquarters of [[Pemex]], the [[Mexico|Mexican]] state oil company.<ref name=abc>{{cite news|last=Weissenstein |first=Michael |title=14 Dead, 80 Injured in Mexico Oil Company Blast |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/explosion-pemex-headquarters-workers-injured-18370505 |accessdate=1 February 2013 |newspaper=[[ABC News]] |date=31 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E7Jj0E0d?url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/explosion-pemex-headquarters-workers-injured-18370505 |archivedate= 1 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> At least 37 people died and another 126 were injured when an explosion occurred in a building adjacent to the main tower.<ref>{{cite news|last=L. Montalvo|first=Tania|title=Las cifra de muertos tras la explosión en Pemex aumenta a 37|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2013/02/04/autoridades-trabajan-en-la-identificacion-de-la-ultima-victima-de-pemex|accessdate=4 February 2013|newspaper=CNNMéxico|date=4 February 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=reuters>{{cite news|title=Mexico blast kills at least 33, flagging Pemex safety woes |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/01/us-mexico-pemex-idUSBRE90U1FF20130201 |accessdate=1 February 2013 |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=1 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E7K1QL54?url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/01/us-mexico-pemex-idUSBRE90U1FF20130201 |archivedate= 1 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Earlier in the day, Pemex sent out a [[Twitter|tweet]] saying that the building was being evacuated due to a "problem with the electrical system" in the complex that includes the skyscraper.<ref name=huffpost>{{cite news|title=14 dead, 80 injured in Mexico oil company blast|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-wires/20130131/lt-mexico-pemex-fire/?ir=style|accessdate=1 February 2013|agency=Associated Press |work= [[Huffington Post]]|date=31 January 2013}}</ref>
==Incident== At about {{nowrap|3:45 pm}} [[central time zone|local time]], an explosion occurred in the basement of a parking garage adjacent to the main office building.<ref name="abc"/> The blast caused the first two stories of the fourteen-floor Building B-2 to partially collapse.<ref name="abc"/> The cause of the blast was a gas leak that was ignited by an electrical fault.<ref name="USA Today">{{cite news|title=Official: Gas leak caused Mexico oil company blast|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/02/04/mexico-explosion/1892017/?dlvrit=206567|work=USA Today|accessdate=5 February 2013|date=4 February 2013}}</ref>
==Aftermath== [[File:Explosión en torre de PEMEX.jpg|left|thumb|Site after explosion]] An evacuation of the area had been begun in the minutes following the explosion.<ref name="cnn">{{cite news|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2013/01/31/explosion-rocks-oil-company-office/ |title=At least 14 dead, 80 injured after blast rocks oil company office |publisher=CNN |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=1 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E7HcQe0X?url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2013/01/31/explosion-rocks-oil-company-office/ |archivedate= 1 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In the hours after the blast, about 30 people were reported to be trapped in debris,<ref name="cnn"/> and searches continued into the next day, as Pemex CEO Emilio Lozoya said there were indications that some people remained under the rubble.<ref name="bbc"/>
An initial estimate of casualties, given by a Mexico City government official about two hours after the explosion, was of about five dead and 75 injured.<ref name="cnn"/> By evening, the Mexican interior minister said that the death toll had risen to fourteen, with 80 injuries.<ref name="cnn"/> {{As of|2013|02|01}}, the death toll stood at 33 and was expected to rise, according to a paramedic at the site.<ref name="reuters"/> There were 12 men and 20 women who were confirmed to have died, along with 121 people injured, 52 of which remained in the hospital the day after the explosion.<ref name="bbc">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21289850 |title=Mexico City blast: Hunt for survivors in Pemex building |publisher=BBC News |date=1 February 2013 |accessdate=1 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E7HYHvnn?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21289850 |archivedate= 1 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> By 4 February, the death toll had risen to 37, with three more bodies uncovered and the death of an injured woman.<ref name="la times"/>
An estimated 500 rescuers<ref name="bbc"/> were working at the site through the day on 1 February 2013, including firefighters, military personnel, and Red Cross workers, aided by dogs and a crane.<ref name="abc"/> Four helicopters were used to evacuate those injured, in addition to ambulances.<ref name="bbc"/> While rescue operations were underway, police cordoned off the area around the office complex.<ref name="bbc"/>
On 4 February 2013, it was announced by Attorney-General [[Jesus Murillo Karam]] that the explosion was caused when a buildup of gas in the basement was ignited by a spark, from what was believed to be an electrical fault.<ref name="USA Today"/> According to Murillo, the explosion had expanded outwards, consistent with a gas explosion, rather than remaining focused in one spot, as a bomb would have done, and none of the victims had injuries of the types associated with bombings.<ref name="la times">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-mexico-gas-blast-20130204,0,6289235.story |title=Mexico official says deadly Pemex blast caused by gas |work=Los Angeles Times |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=5 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EDIC8mli?url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-mexico-gas-blast-20130204%2C0%2C6289235.story |archivedate= 5 February 2013 |first=Tracy |last=Wilkinson |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Reactions== Through [[Twitter]], [[President of Mexico]] [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] wrote: "I have ordered the relevant authorities to implement rescue protocols and the investigation of the facts. The priority right now is to attend to the injured and to safeguard the physical integrity of those who work there".<ref name="Twitter@EPN">{{cite tweet |author= [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] |user= EPN|number= 297136398916546560 |date= 31 January 2013 |title= He ordenado a las autoridades correspondientes implementar los protocolos de rescate y la investigación de los hechos |access-date= 31 January 2013 }}</ref> He also sent his condolences to relatives: "I deeply regret the death of fellow PEMEX workers. My condolences to their families".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.excelsior.com.mx/2013/01/31/nacional/882108| accessdate = 1 February 2013 | title = EPN envía condolencias a familiares de víctimas de explosión en Pemex | date = 31 January 2013 | language = Spanish | publisher = Excélsior}}</ref> Peña Nieto also established three days of national mourning.<ref>{{cite news|last=Resendiz|first=Francisco|title=Decreta Peña Nieto tres días de luto nacional|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/900218.html |newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)]] |date=1 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202011344/http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/900218.html |archivedate=2 February 2013|language=Spanish |deadurl=no |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref>
The Director General of Pemex, Emilio Lozoya Austin, tweeted: "My condolences to all the families of workers at Pemex who have lost loved ones in the explosion of today".<ref name="Twitter@EmilioLozoyaAus">{{cite tweet |author= Emilio Lozoya Austin |user= EmilioLozoyaAus|number= 297163969829937152 |date= 31 January 2013 |title= Mi más sentido pésame a todas las familias de los trabajadores de @pemex que han perdido a sus seres queridos por la explosión de hoy |access-date= 31 January 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.excelsior.com.mx/2013/01/31/comunidad/882124 |title = Funcionarios expresan sus condolencias por tragedia en Torre de Pemex | publisher = Excélsior | language = Spanish| accessdate = 1 February 2013| date = 1 February 2013}}</ref>
Former [[National Action Party (Mexico)|National Action Party]] presidential candidate [[Gustavo Madero Muñoz]], the governors of [[Guerrero]], [[Zacatecas]], [[Veracruz]], [[Morelos]], [[Tabasco]], and [[Oaxaca]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/899974.html| publisher= El Universal |language= Spanish |accessdate= 1 February 2013 |date= 31 January 2013 |title= Torre Pemex – Goberndaores lamentan fallecimientos}}</ref> and the Finance Minister, Luis Videgaray Caso,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/899961.html| language = Spanish | accessdate = 1 February 2013 | date = 31 January 2013 | title = Videgaray de pesame por fallecidos en explosion}}</ref> and several senators<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/899968.html | publisher = El Universal | title = Torre Pemex Senadores lamentan decesos| accessdate = 1 February 2013 | date = 31 January 2013}}</ref> also sent their condolences and expressed solidarity with the families of the victims. <!-- ==Timeline== {{Prose|section|date=February 2013}} *15:55:16 There is an explosion between the basement and first floor of building B2 of the Pemex executive tower; the explosion is accompanied by a perceptible tremor in the building and in nearby areas. *16:05 The spokesman for Pemex confirms that the explosion caused damage to the ground floor.<ref name="cronologia">Cronologia Explosion en la Torre de Pemex Ciudad de Mexico 31 January 2013 El Universal http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/900006.html#1</ref> *16:20 The building is completely evacuated. *16:30 The area and streets surrounding the tower are cordoned off. *16:50 There is an initial estimate of 30 injured.<ref name="cronologia"/> *16:55 The head of government of the Federal District, Miguel Angel Mancera, accompanied by rescue workers, begins rescue efforts in the area of the incident.<ref name="cronologia"/> *17:00 Tenty six people are confirmed injured, several of them are relocated to nearby hospitals.<ref name="cronologia"/> *17:05 The Governor of the State of Mexico, Avila Villegas Eruviel, sends the Lightning Rescue Team to transport the injured.<ref name="cronologia"/> *17:15 The Secretary of the Interior, Miguel Angel Osorio Chong, arrives in the vicinity of the tower.<ref name="cronologia"/> *17:20 Miguel Angel Mancera says that there are rescuers and rescue dogs working within the tower.<ref name="cronologia"/> *17:30 The Attorney General, Jesús Murillo Karam, arrives in the vicinity of the tower.<ref name="cronologia"/> *17:54 The first death is confirmed. *18:00 It is reported there will be will no workers in the Administrative Center of Pemex until further notice.<ref name="cronologia"/> *18:10 Ten deaths are confirmed. *18:20 Fourteen deaths are confirmed and the number of injured is increased to 80. *18:30 The union of Pemex reports that the tragedy was due to lack of maintenance.<ref name="cronologia"/> *18:35 President Enrique Peña Nieto orders investigations begin what triggered the incident<ref name="cronologia"/> *19:00 The number of injured at is increased to 100. *19:05 The death of another victim in hospital is announced. *19:07 It is assumed that there are about 30 people trapped in the tower.<ref>http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/899965.html</ref> *19:10 President Enrique Peña Nieto arrives in the vicinity of the tower.<ref name="cronologia"/> *19:20 The National Defense Secretariat applies the DN-IIIE Plan.<ref name="cronologia"/> *19:30 The governors of the states of Guerrero, Zacatecas and Veracruz pledge their solidarity with the families of the victims of the explosion. *19:55 Former presidential candidate Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador laments the tragedy. *21:15 It is assumed that the number of injuries and fatalities will increase. *21:20 A victim is rescued alive who was trapped in the building.{{cn}} *21:30 Surveillance in the vicinity of the tower is increased to continue the search and the investigation of what caused the incident. *21:40 A list of the injured and the dead is released.<ref>Entereate lsita de heridos El Universal 01 de febrero http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/899956.html</ref> *22:10 The Marines abandon the Pemex facilities, due to the risk of the collapse of the tower.<ref>Abandonan las labores de rescate en Pemex por riesgo Redacción y Notimex | Nacional 2013-01-31 | Hora de creación: 22:26:34 | Ultima modificación: 22:26:34 http://www.cronica.com.mx/nota.php?id_nota=727188</ref> *22:30 President Enrique Peña Nieto speaks to the nation. *23:00 Interior Minister Miguel Angel Osorio Chong gives a press conference. *23:03 The tower is evacuated in the face of warnings of collapse.<ref>Evacuan edificio de Pemex por alerta Gerardo Olvera y Benito Jiménez Ciudad de México (31 enero 2013) http://www.elnorte.com/libre/online07/preacceso/articulos/default.aspx?plazaconsulta=elnorte&url=http://www.elnorte.com/nacional/articulo/728/1454886/&urlredirect=http://www.elnorte.com/nacional/articulo/728/1454886/?titulo=evacuan-edificio-de-pemex-por-alerta</ref> *23:10 The death toll is increased to 25.<ref>Suman 25 muertos por explosion en torre de Pemex el universal Feb 1 2013 http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/900010.html</ref> *23:20 The bodies of the deceased are moved to the Forensic Medical Center.<ref>Trasladan a muertos al Forense de la PGR El Universal Jueves, 31 enero 2013 23:08 Nacional http://pulsoslp.com.mx/2013/01/31/trasladan-a-muertos-al-forense-de-la-pgr/</ref> -->

page.title: Trade Unions International of Chemical, Oil and Allied Workers

revision.text:
[[File:ICPS_Trade_Union_Logo.jpg|thumb|Logo of the ICPS]]
The '''Trade Unions International of Chemical, Oil and Allied Workers''' was a [[trade union international]] affiliated with the [[World Federation of Trade Unions]]. It was often known by its French initials, ICPS (Union Internationale des Syndicats des Industries, Chimiques, du Petroles et Similares).
== History ==
The Union was established at a conference in [[Budapest]], [[People's Republic of Hungary|Hungary]] in March 1950 as the Trade Unions International of Chemical and Allied Workers. It changed its name in 1954 when it expanded its scope to include [[Oil industry|oil workers]]. It also represented workers in the [[glassware]], [[paper industry|paper]] and [[ceramic]] industries.<ref>''[http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/100074996 Directory of World Federation of Trade Unions]'' Washington [[Office of International Labor Affairs]], December 1958 p.52</ref>
In 1998 a Conference was held in [[Havana]] which merged [[Trade Unions International of Miners|Trade Unions International of Energy Workers]] (formerly known as the Trade Unions International of Miners) and [[Trade Union International of Metal and Engineering Workers]] to form the Trade Union International of Energy, Metal, Chemical, Oil and Allied Industries. This organization was reorganized again as the [[Trade Union International of Energy Workers (2007)|Trade Unions International of Energy Workers]] in 2007. This left the metal workers an opportunity create a new TUI the next year, [[Trade Union International of Workers in the Mining, the Metallurgy and the Metal Industries]].<ref name="Project for Articles of Association">[http://www.tuimm.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/ESTATUTUAK.pdf Project for Articles of Association] p.16</ref><ref name="London p.342">''[[Europa World Year Book]]'' London; Taylor & Francis, 2004 p.342</ref>
== Organization ==
The TUI was governed by an international trade conference held every four years. The Conference drew up the groups program, made policy decisions and elected an administrative committee. The latter consisted of 25 members drawn from 20 countries and met once a year. The bureau, composed of the TUI president, vice-presidents, general secretary and secretaries met to ensure the fulfillment of the administrative committees decisions and a permanent secretariat oversaw day-to-day operations.<ref>[[A. Percy Coldrick|Coldrick, A. Percy]] and [[Philip James Jones|Jones, Philip]]. ''The international directory of the trade union movement'' New York : Facts on File, [1978] p.179</ref> Industrial Commissions were also set up to deal with specific issues. In 1978 there commissions on oil ([[drilling]], [[refining]], [[oil pipelines]], [[distribution (business)|distribution]]), chemicals-pharmaceuticals, [[paper board]], [[pulp (paper)|pulp]], [[cellulose]], [[rubber]], glass and ceramics.<ref>Coldrick and Jones p.194</ref>
In 1955 its headquarters were reported to be in [[Bucharest]], [[People's Republic of Romania|Romania]].<ref>''[http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/100074996 Directory of World Federation of Trade Unions]'' Washington [[Office of International Labor Affairs]], June 1955 p.49</ref> In 1958 its headquarters was reported to be at 17 [[Sztalin ter]], [[Budapest]] [[Districts of Budapest|VI]], [[People's Republic of Hungary|Hungary]].<ref>''Directory of World Federation of Trade Unions'' 1958 p.52</ref> From 1978 to 1989 it was reported to be at 1415 Budapest, sometimes given the street name [[Benczur ut]] 45.<ref>''[https://archive.org/details/dudeman5685_yahoo_WFTU The World Federation of Trade Unions, 1945-1985. ]'' Prague; Published by the WTFU in cooperation with PRACE Czechoslovak Trade Unions 1985 p.150</ref><ref> [[John Coggins|Coggins, John]] ''Trade unions of the world 1989-1990'' Harlow : Longman, 1989 2nd ed. p.451</ref> In 1991 it was reported at EM26, H 1097.<ref>[[Martin Upham|Upham, Martin]] ''Trade unions of the world, 1992-1993.'' Harlow, Essex, U.K. : Longman ; Detroit, Mich. : Distributed exclusively in the U.S. and Canada by Gale Research Inc., 1991 p.558</ref>
== Membership ==
In 1958 the ICPS claimed membership in 25 countries.<ref>''Directory of World Federation of Trade Unions]'' December 1958 p.52</ref> In 1976 it claimed 7 million members in 59 affiliated unions in 37 countries.<ref>Coldrick and Jones p.178</ref> In 1985 it claimed 13 million members in 100 affiliate in 50 countries.<ref>Coldrick and Jones p.180</ref><ref>''The World Federation of Trade Unions, 1945-1985'' p.150</ref>
In 1975 the following unions were affiliated with ICPS:<ref>Coldrick and Jones p.181</ref>
*{{flag|Albania|1946}} - [[Conseil Central des Unions Professionelles]] *{{flag|Argentina}} - [[Federacion Argentina de Trabajadores de la Industia Quimicas y Afines]] *{{flag|Austria}} - [[Fraktion Gewerkschaftlicher Linksblock in der Gewerkschaft der Chemiearbeiter]] *{{flag|Benin|1975}} - [[Syndicat National de Travailleurs des Industries Alimentaires et Chimiques, Hotels-Bar, Cafes-Restaurants]] *{{flag|Bulgaria|1967}} - [[Syndicat des Travailleurs de l'Industrie Chimique]] *{{flag|Bulgaria|1967}} - [[Syndicat des Travailleurs de l'Industrie Legare]] *{{flag|Chile}} - [[Sindicato Unico Nacional de Trabajadores de Quimica y Fammaceutica y Ramos Afines]] *{{flag|Chile}} - [[Sindicato Unico de Trabajadores del Plastico]] *{{flag|China}} - [[Oil Workers' Union]] *{{flag|China}} - [[Trade Union of Workers in Heavy Industry]] *{{flag|Colombia}} - [[Federación de los Trabajadores de Petrole]] *{{flag|Congo|1970}} - [[Fédération des Travailleurs des Mines, Petrol, Energie et Assimiles]] *{{flag|Cuba}} - [[Sindicato Nacional de Trabajadores de la Industria Basicos]] *{{flag|Cuba}} - [[Sindicato Nacional de Trabajadores del Petrole]] *{{flag|Czechoslovakia}} - [[Federation of Chemical, Paper, Glass and Printing Workers]] *{{flag|Ecuador}} - [[Federación Nacional de Trabajadores del Petrole]] *{{flag|France}} - [[Fédération Nationale des Industries Chimiques]], [[CGT (France)|CGT]] *{{flag|France}} - [[Fédération des Travailleurs des Industies Papetiers]], CGT *{{flag|France}} - [[Fédération Nationale des Travailleurs du Verre]], CGT *{{flag|France}} - [[Fédération Nationale des Travailleurs de la Ceramique]] *{{flag|East Germany}} - [[Industriegewerkschaft Chemie, Glas und Keramik]] *{{flag|East Germany}} - [[IG Druk und Papier]] *{{flag|Ghana}} - [[General Transport, Petroleum and Chemical Workers' Union]] *{{flag|Hungary|1957}} - [[Chemical Workers' Union (Hungary)|Chemical Workers' Union]] *{{flag|Hungary|1957}} - [[Printing, Paper and Press Workers Unions]] *{{flag|Hungary|1957}} - [[Building and Building Materials Industry Workers Union]] *{{flag|India}} - [[All India Pharmaceutical Employees' Union]] *{{flag|India}} - [[All India Chemical and Pharmaceutical Employees' Federation]] *{{flag|India}} - [[All India Indian Oxygen and Acetyne Employees' Federation]] *{{flag|India}} - [[Oil and Natural Gas Commission Karamchari Union]] *{{flag|India}} - [[Antibiotics Project Karamchari Sangh]] *{{flag|Indonesia}} - [[Oil Workers' Union]] (PERBUM) *{{flag|Iraq|1963}} - [[General Trade Union of Oil Industry, Minerals and Chemical Workers]] *{{flag|Italy}} - [[Federazione Italiana Lavoratori Poligraficie Cartai]] *{{flag|Jordan}} - [[General Federation of Jordanian Trade Unions]] *{{flag|Kenya}} - [[Kenya Petroleum Oil Workers Union]] *{{flag|North Korea}} - [[Trade Union of Chemical Industry Workers]] *{{flag|Kuwait}} - [[Workers' and Employees' Petroleum Trade Union]] *{{flag|Madagascar}} - [[Union Nationale des Travailleurs du Petrole, du Livre Papier et du Artes Graphiques]] *{{flag|Nigeria}} - [[Gulf Oil Company (Nigeria) Employees and General Workers Union]] *{{flag|Peru}} - [[Federación de Trabajadores de la Industia de Plasticos y Afines]] *{{flag|Poland}} - [[Federation of Chemical Workers Unions]] *{{flag|Poland}} - [[Union des Syndicats de l'Industry du Bois (Papier Carton)]] *{{flag|Romania|1965}} - [[Federation of Chemical Workers Unions]] *{{flag|Soviet Union}} - [[Oil, Chemical and Gas Workers Union]] *{{flag|Soviet Union}} - [[Building and Building Materials Workers Union]] *{{flag|Soviet Union}} - [[Timber, Paper and Wood Workers Union]] *{{flag|Soviet Union}} - [[Public Health Workers Union]] *{{flag|Sri Lanka}} - [[Lanka Petroleum Employees' Union]] *{{flag|Sri Lanka}} - [[Ceylon State Corporation Employees' Union]] *{{flag|Sudan}} - [[Federation of Petroleum Workers]] *{{flag|Syria}} - [[Professional Federation of Petroleum, Electricity and]] *{{flag|Uruguay}} - [[Federación ANCAP]] *{{flag|Uruguay}} - [[Federación Obrera de la Industria del Vidrio]] *{{flag|Venezuela}} - [[Glass Workers Federation]] *{{flag|Vietnam}} - [[National Union of Chemical Workers]] *{{flag|South Yemen}} - [[General Union of Petroleum Workers]]
== Publications ==
The Union published an ''Information Bulletin'' and ''Information Sheet''.<ref>Coldrick and Jones p.180</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
